Google hires ex-Apple chipset veteran to help design SoCs for Pixel phones Ryne Hager Follow View All Posts 2017/06/13 11:36am PDTJun 13, 2017 46 Plus 1 on G+ 195 Share on Facebook 52 Share on Twitter Total Shares293 Google News Google's hardware plans for the future are getting bigger. Variety is reporting that Google has hired Manu Gulati, a hardware architect, away from Apple. Gulati is reported as having previously played a significant role in the development of Apple's SoCs for the last eight years and was hired sometime in the last few weeks. His new title at Google is Lead SOC Architect, and he's expected to work on custom chipsets for future Pixel phones. If Manu Gulati can apply the same black magic to Google's future products as he did on Apple's custom chips, things could be fantastic. Apple's "A" series chips are amazing pieces of hardware. Though Apple does license ARM's tech, unlike other manufacturers, they don't just toss the licensed reference designs on a wafer. Apple has bent over backward to optimize their silicon architecture for iOS, and the resulting performance on Apple devices definitely demonstrates that. Although some Android chipset vendors, such as Qualcomm, do make custom designs like the Kryo, for whatever reason Apple's custom hardware (combined with their software) has held an edge in performance for years. For most of us, any advantage the A series chips have doesn't make any difference without the Android operating system. But if Google is able to bring the same degree of performance enhancements and customization over into their future hardware, the future of Android SoC performance could be bright. After the dark and regressive ages of the Snapdragon 808/810 and Qualcomm's rushed 64bit development cycle, I would like nothing more than to see Google bring a first party chipset in a future Pixel device. And who knows, they might even sell it to other manufacturers, increasing competition in the currently stagnant mobile chipset space. Gulati joining Google finally lends credence to the old stories of Google's interest in SoC designing. And it appears to be full steam ahead, as supplemental job postings for SoC design have appeared on Google Careers. Whether these efforts result in a new custom chipset by Google, or we just see some new specialized hardware for machine learning, either way, things should be interesting. Source: Linkedin Via: Variety Tags apple ARM chipset hardware SoC subscribe ... Previous Story [Lame] Netflix places limits on how many times you can download certain content ... Duder12 HUGE kabiluddin Guess we'll see the new custom soc in late 2018/9 Honestly can't wait. destinyhud pixel 3 then!!! Godspoken I recall "Google silicon" being referenced last year as a future goal of the Pixel, very exciting. blackice85 Isn't that one of the things holding them back from providing updates for longer periods of time too? Could be a big deal not just for the performance gains. Gregory That Project Treble thing or how do you call it in O is also all about cutting on dependencies from third parties like Qualcomm. blackice85 Oh I hadn't heard about that, I bet this is one aspect of it then. Duder12 Project Treble doesnt improve years of update support. It brings updates faster since Qualcomm and OEMs can work on software updates at the same time. Qualcomm can still decide to not ship new drivers for old versions of Android just like they always have. Google doing their own SOC is the only real answer Gregory From my understanding, it eliminates the need for the drivers to be updated in the first place. someone755 You can't expect to not update drivers with new Android versions. Say there's an Android system API that a driver adheres to. As something banal, let's say we have a driver that controls whether the hardware button backlight is on or off, and that the system can control whether it is either on or off. Then a newer Android version appears which supports both the old API but also a newer one, wherein the hardware backlight can be controlled as if it were analog (from 0-255 for example). Then, the third system version comes out that ditches support for the old API and only still supports the newer one. Yes the OEM could hack things up so that values 0-254 would mean the light is off and then 255 would mean it's on, but this further complicates both the user experience and app compatibility as well as future system version compatibility. At this point if you want a stable and future-proof software solution, you absolutely have to update the driver to support the new API. And if the backlight vendor can't provide one, then it's more trouble than it's worth for the OEM to do the hack themselves and they just post a note online saying your device won't get upgraded, leaving you with no choice but to either resort to community hacks or buy a new device. Yes the example is completely idiotic but it serves as an example of why you can't go around updating devices without driver updates. Aside from the functionality aspect there are many security flaws that could affect a driver. And not updating that huge gaping hole in your security while providing monthly 'security patches' that claim to solve security threats is just inane. At that point why even bother with security patches if you can't expect chipset vendors to fix the problems in their closed-source firmware, or hold them accountable for it. Gregory While I completely understand your point, I'd like to extend it to say that there could be such a backlight that can be either on or off, and it's a hardware limitation, so it isn't possible to fully implement the new API on that device. I mean, hardware configurations vary, it's a matter of fact. The point of HAL (hardware abstraction layer) is to abstract away the differences across the underlying hardware, and provide a unified API for the system services to interact with said hardware. If the HAL doesn't provide support for some new feature that was added in a system update but the hardware could technically support it, it still means that the system would behave as though that feature isn't supported by the hardware, and that's it. I'd rather have a device that doesn't support that new feature than a device that is no longer updated. And security... How about people ALWAYS check for buffer boundaries before copying memory? What do they do with all that time and disk space they save? Or, at least, if they're that lazy, run a static analyzer on your code and fix whatever it finds. And run it in valgrind to find memory leaks. It's not that hard to write vulnerability-free code from the start. someone755 But a device will never pass certification, either by Google or an FCC-like entity or another office, with broken features. This is exactly why the 8974 line got dropped -- the hardware didn't support a feature that Google wanted so they didn't let any 8974 device pass CTS. How do you think people running Nougat just fine on their hammerheads (via one custom ROM or another) feel about this conundrum when they've been cut short an entire system update because of Google's insane chip requirements? It's easy to know how to prevent bad code but often times projects start simple and private and unoptimized, and then grow into something much larger that's hard to maintain. A classic example is Android itself (look at all the memory leaks that L introduced). Gregory Well... If a device passed certification by Google (CTS) and carriers, that feature was optional from the beginning, right? Android does already support a plethora of different hardware configurations with different capabilities. If a device didn't have some feature at launch, I don't expect it to have that feature enabled with a software update. CTS is about keeping compatibility with apps (it tests public APIs), it has nothing to do with drivers and hardware. There are literally no hardware requirements that make it impossible to update existing devices more than a year or two. Carrier certification is about device interfacing correctly with carrier equipment, it did so well when it was released and certified, so just don't touch the modem firmware because it's already doing its job good enough, as simple as that. There are exactly zero reasons to modify the HAL for system updates provided HAL and the rest of the system are properly separated, which, from my understanding, they are with Project Treble. It also adds CTS-like standardized test suite for these things. What the hell is 8974? someone755 Msm8974. The Snapdragon 800 platform that phones like the N5, Z3, G2, S5, M8 etc were based on. That got blocked from receiving any sort of updates because Google decided that Vulkan or GL 3.1 was necessary for the upgrade. Not that modern low-end phones are capable of performing the task that the requirement was set for anyways. Basically the thing my entire argument is set around but alright... Owais Lone > Qualcomm can still decide to not ship new drivers for old versions of Android just like they always have. ... and Project Treble will enable device vendors to still ship updates in this exact case. Project Treble cuts out qualcom and SoC manufacturers out of the update cycle. The device vendors will be bottleneck and decision makers now. someone755 This is incorrect. Please see my reply to Gregory above. Owais Lone Your example exactly illustrates the problem now. Project Treble is supposed to abstract these internal hardware level ABIs/APIs so vendors don't have to re-implement the whole layer again. Only time when SOC vendors will have to update their code is when Project Treble itself comes out with a breaking change and a major version upgrade. Of course, vendors might have to or want to make changes here and there but the abstraction should save them from re-doing all of it on every update and if the vendor does not want to improve/optimize with every update, they shouldn't have to make any changes at all unless Treble itself comes out with an incompatible update. someone755 And say that Android P is the one where the button backlight brightness from my example becomes an analog value and the digital on/off API is dropped. Then the phones that incorporate this function will either have to have the driver updated or will not get updated to the next Android version. This is a problem and always will be, as long as chip vendors are not held responsible and held to a higher standard, and as long as the entities that certify devices for daily use (CTS, FCC etc) have some standards themselves (in the sense of not letting devices with broken/missing core features pass). Owais Lone If such a change happens at the HW level, it'll be abstracted at the treble API level so phones that leverage treble API will not need any change at all. Vendors would need to update their code if the change happened in Treble's apI itself which is extremely unlikely as it'll defeat the purpose of having Treble in the first place. That said, there will be major updates to Treble which might break backward compatibility but it's Google's job to keep those changes at a minimal or the whole idea will be worthless. someone755 This is exactly what I'm saying -- if Treble changes (which it most probably will across Android versions, as the system has changed until now), the chip vendors will *have* to provide updates. And there is no way around this limitation, Treble or not, if Google makes some absurd changes then phones won't get updated. Owais Lone Yes, that is true but why would that happen in the first place? That would completely defeat the purpose. Treble will most likely always be backward compatible. It'll probably only add new features and new APIs but not break existing ones. That's how I would handle the project. So i will repeat, its not that Intel cant beat Apple, its that they dont need to. Its made even worse by the fact that most laptops are seriously storage speed limited, even an SSD only helps so much, and the CPU is still waiting. The A10, in a laptop would be awful. One core would be almost always in use for background tasks, and as such would burn through battery. Android is not that dissimilar, it has far more background activity than iOS, and therefore needs less powerful, more numerous cores that use less power. The trick is making all those cores useful when you need to run a single powerful task. This is something that Android has got much better at, but it doesnt really show up well in benchmarks. ARM has done extensive testing of such setups, but has rejected them for a reason. Thinker Let's test your knowledge since you claim to know so much...how many instruction set per cycle can A10 do vs S835? No, Samsung and Qualcomm do NOT use custom design cores dumbass. What you wrote is pure ignorance. Please stop. Just_No_Stop Qualcomm do use custom designs, Samsung doesnt, and yet the Exynos 8895 is faster than the A10.. It seems you are the ignorant one. Thinker Wrong. Anandtech: "The new Kryo 280, despite the similar name, shares no design DNA with the original Kryo. Its an octa-core, big.LITTLE configuration with four “performance” cores and four lower-power “efficiency” cores. What makes Kryo 280 unique, however, is that it’s the first design to use ARM’s new "Built on ARM Cortex Technology" (BoC) license, which allows vendors to customize ARM cores. This new semi-custom option gives vendors the ability to differentiate their products from those using ARM’s stock cores while avoiding the more costly route of creating a fully-custom design from scratch." Again, like I said above, S835 CPU core was a step BACKWARDS. It is basically a generic CPU core with memory controller from Qualcomm. S820 used custom cores but with S835, Qualcomm used generic. Again, you never answered my other question. How many instruction set per cycle can A10 do vs S835? STFU dude. You are ignorant. Just_No_Stop You realise that a SoC isnt just the cores right? The memory controller and GPU are what make the 835 custom. If the 835 and the Exynos are generic then why is the Exynos faster despite a lower clock? Again, you lack understanding, all you can do is regurgitate rubbish you have read on a website. Exynos is almost entirely ARM reference, the 835 is not, generic cores maybe, but otherwise completely custom. Sadly all that customisation results in lower performance, not more. Why does it matter how many instructions per cycle it can do? What matters is the total performance. Instructions per cycle is a very old fashioned way of looking at CPU speed, more so than ever now with multicore setups and microcode interpretors. yet again you show a complete lack of understanding about how a modern SoC works. Anyone could design a CPU like the A10, only apple does, because only Apple need one like that, it doesnt show genius, or more advanced design, its just different to similarly performing ARM and Intel CPUs. Frankly I'm just blocking you now, since you arent interested in learning. Thinker Damn you're ignorant. I see that you're backtracking like crazy!! Lol No, S835 CPU core is generic. PhaseBurn Google's been in the hardware field for a very, very long time, originally using Scorpion ARM-based CPUs that predate the SnapDragon, even (https://www.wired.com/2012/09/pluto-switch/). Despite what Variety says about Gulati joining to design SoCs for the Pixel line, I'm guessing that their internal SoC group will end up working on a lot of their platform networking and datacenter fabric next generation designs, in addition to anything they do on a future Pixel phone. Shelly-Man Vol 2 I'm pretty excited to hear about this news. I've always wanna see Google have their own custom chips for their hardware. Google love plot twist #2 roberto.elena I'm personally more interested in a Google SoC for Chromebooks. It's not that I don't find this news interesting for mobiles, but the biggest benefit, even more important than improved performance, is extended OS support. At the current pace of hardware improvement, I'm not interested in owning a phone for more than 1 or 2 years, but a Chromebook is a different story. I would keep it for several years. destinyhud good point. intel is fast but have issues with android apps. other oem are not that fast enough and qualcomm wont come to chromebook at least for now. so this chip used in chromebook pixel would be awesome Midnitte Sort of wish somebody (Intel, AMD,.... Google) would purchase MediaTek and position them to actually compete with Snapdragon, so that we could all benefit from longer/quicker upgrades, not to mention performance. someone755 MediaTek's strategy is much like AMD's was just a few years ago in the desktop space. The money for them is up to where OEMs (who make low-end and midrange phones) are willing to pay for the chips -- any higher and they don't have the knowledge/technology/budget to produce something more powerful. Any lower and, well, this is as low as it can go, and the other competitors (Qualcomm, Intel) have worse-performing chips available for the price that MediaTek offers theirs at. Why that is, I have no clue, but I suspect it could have something to do with Qcom having a monopoly on ARM-based chips, and Intel thinking that their overpriced-desktop-chips-with-no-competitor strategy is going to work here, in a highly competitive environment. The point here being that MediaTek works off tight margins and sells in large quantities. Restructuring this process so that it fits our idea of a Qualcomm competitor would be expensive, and definitely riskier than what the payoff is worth to the investor. reggjoo Maybe he can help bring that single core performance up to apple levels. It won't really make a big difference in the global grand scheme of things, but it would kill all that bragging rights talk. usamaisawake I know we can never know, but I honestly think that the A-chips are, on their own, just really damn good chips. iOS optimization helps, but I think a lot of it is Apple's designers. Marty I'm liking the sound of that. But going by Google's declaration that the Pixel phones are made by Google when in fact they are designed and made by HTC, these SoCs will probably be shelf-bought from the cheapest vendor. destinyhud i am sorry u r wrong at this part. designed by google and made by HTC. same like apples designed by apple claim. Marty Wrong. It's now known the Pixels were designed and made by HTC. http://www.androidauthority.com/google-hidden-htc-involvement-google-pixel-xl-code-723953/ https://www.forbes.com/sites/jeanbaptiste/2016/10/05/the-pixel-smartphone-is-actually-made-by-htc-not-google/#52ca3eb1e99a https://www.androidcentral.com/google-pixel-htc-will-real-manufacturer-googles-phones-share-glory destinyhud its now knows to just u or what?? because eveyone know its designed by google. but they def have HTC previous device influence. google interview clearly said they tried to design pixel as non iphone design as possible. we are talking about hardware. finding code reference is not equal to HTC made hardware. how does that login even correlate? all the article u posted said it is made by HTC and i didnt disagree on that. it is made by HTC but designed by Google. try harder. https://www.cnet.com/special-reports/google-pixel-how-google-designed-its-first-real-phone/ Marty Read the AA article. It clearly shows HTC footprints in both hardware and software design. destinyhud AA article says nothing about hardware footprint just software foot print. software is not hardware. also there are similar article which said google was building nexus by HTC and finally decided to make their own phone which is why u could find htc code when it was in early development. we are not talking about software here again. Marty The HTC hardware footprint is clearly seen in the design. And it's noteworthy that the software would have any OEM influence at all since Android is a Google creation. You can claim whatever you want, but the evidence is clear and has been clear since the Pixels were released. Talk to the hand... needa But once you open up the phone, you can see that HTC did not design the hardware inside of it. That is always the tell tale sign. matteventu Yes and the htc logo on the battery is there because they just wanted to sign it? needa HTC doesn't have a battery manufacturing plant (assumption). It's part of being the ODM. Designing a PCB and ordering a battery to fit in a specified area are two completely different things. matteventu Dont waste your time with this bunch of G-fanboys... Marty Agreed. One thing, though, they seem to always forget is "Made by Google" when the Pixel isn't made by Google. Apple doesn't even say that about the iPhone, though every aspect of the iPhone is Apple all the way. But Google gets a pass on that lie because, as you said, they're G-fanboys. They always present excuses like..."well, it was designed by Google, that means it's made by Google." The Pixel isn't even designed by Google much less made by Google. But I guess since Google decided to lie, the chose to go all out on the lie... "This lie made by Google" Heh...Google did design and make something...lol...a lie. saf1927 If they do indeed design the SoC in-house, obviously they won't actually manufacture them since they don't own any semiconductor company, just like Apple. They will hand in the specifications to a foundry such as TSMC. Marty You'd think they'd do it that way, but Google did lie about the origin of the Pixels. If Google were to emphatically state that a future SoC is designed and engineered by them, who knows if it would be true? whispy_snippet Fucking awesome. Kimmy Gibbler I don't expect them to succeed Total Insecurity The future of Android is bright anyway :) Jordan L So this means Pixel 3 is going to be an awesome phone! I'm with a lot of people here in hoping for a cheaper Pixel. Like $399. Pixel 2, Pixel 2 XL, and Pixel Base. I guess this mimicks Apples plan with iPhone 8, and 7s. someone755 Pixel SE. With a 4" display I wouldn't even be mad. Patel Nisha I really hope this turns out to be a big deal, not just some optimisation stuff for 3rd party components. Apple have a HUGE lead now in terms of silicon. Even Samsung’s own chips can’t compete with Apple’s. It can only really be Google who have a chance to catch up at this stage. xyz Good. Now Google fanboys will have one less excuse when Google still doesn't update phones for more than 2 years. Random! I wonder if a new chip design would help to solve the sound latency issue that makes it so frustrating to use apps such as drum emulators on Android. Or if this is really just a matter of optimizing software. Anyway, shouldn't all SoC manufacturers be designing their SoCs with a dedicated microphone co-processor in order to enable always-on hotword/voice recognition which doesn't kill the battery? Maybe that co-processor could also be the one monitoring the sensors... Home News AFL Business Politics World Comment Property Entertainment Lifestyle Travel Cars Tech Sport Video All News Victoria News National Environment Health Education Investigations Galleries Clique Photos Good Weekend NSW News ACT News Queensland WA News Sport AFL Ultimate Footy Cricket Soccer Racing Netball NRL Union Motorsport Basketball Tennis Scores Cycling Golf US Sports Athletics Boxing Swimming News Markets Quotes Workplace Consumer Property Innovation Retail Economy CBD Money Small Business World Politics Politics Political Opinion Video Cartoons The Pulse Federal Election 2016 Your Vote Electorate Map Comment Letters Editorial Obituaries View from the Street Blunt Instrument Satire The Zone Entertainment Movies TV & Radio Music Books Art Stage Melbourne Film Festival What's On in Melbourne Video Box Office Lifestyle News & Views Life & Relationships Health & Wellbeing Beauty Fashion Horoscopes Celebrity Home The Optimist Tech News Security Web Culture Innovation Sci-Tech Gadgets Games eSports Smartphone Apps Mobiles Video News Sport Business Entertainment Lifestyle Travel Property Cars Food Exec Style Parenting Search Site News Markets Quotes Workplace Consumer Retail Economy CBD Money Small Biz Property Innovation Home Business Sponsored June 14 2017 Save Print 8@eight: ASX set to push higher facebook SHARE twitter TWEET email google-plus linkedin reddit More The full attention of the market turns onto the US, but if there was any angst of owning risk assets ahead of the plethora of event risks then it's hard to see where the market has been troubled. Locally, after Tuesday's strong day, shares are set to open moderately higher.  1. FANG rebound: US, European and emerging market equities have found buyers and the notorious FANG basket or FAAMG, or whatever abbreviation of what are effectively market leaders has also rallied. My own basket of Facebook, Amazon, Netflix, Alphabet, Apple and Microsoft has gained 1.2%, and this will still get focus in the session ahead, but specifically, a move in Apple through Friday's close of $148.73 would provide more conviction that tech does not roll over and head south from here. The S&P 500 and Dow Jones have broken out to new all-time highs, with reasonable breadth (77% of S&P 500 companies closed higher on the day), with volumes very much in-line with the 30-day average. Play Video Replay Video Play Video Don't Play Up Next ASX winners and losers - a snapshot Play Video Don't Play Video duration 00:43 More BusinessDay Videos Previous slide Next slide Video duration 04:37 This week all eyes are on Janet Yellen This week all eyes are on Janet Yellen As we go into a new week, the focus will be back on the US Federal Reserve. (This video was produced in commercial partnership between Fairfax Media and IG Markets). Up Next ASX winners and losers - a snapshot Play Video Don't Play Video duration 00:43 Video duration 00:43 ASX winners and losers - a snapshot ASX winners and losers - a snapshot The stand out listings traded on the ASX captured at key moments through the day, as indicated by the time stamp in the video. Up Next Is it time for USD outperformance? Play Video Don't Play Video duration 04:37 Video duration 04:37 Is it time for USD outperformance? Is it time for USD outperformance? With the Fed sounding confident on its inflation outlook and an increasingly hawkish stance, we are seeing green shoots that the USD is ready see better days. Could this pose a problem towards equities? Up Next We should be exempt: Bank executive Play Video Don't Play Video duration 01:50 Video duration 01:50 We should be exempt: Bank executive We should be exempt: Bank executive Find out why the head of the Macquarie Group Nicholas Moore says the bank shouldn't be subjected to the Turnbull government's bank levy. Up Next BHP names new chairman Play Video Don't Play Video duration 00:36 Video duration 00:36 BHP names new chairman BHP names new chairman Ken MacKenzie has been named the next chairman of BHP, taking over from Jac Nasser on September 1. Vision courtesy ABC News Up Next Businesses upset with new food labelling laws Play Video Don't Play Video duration 01:56 Video duration 01:56 Businesses upset with new food labelling ... Businesses upset with new food labelling laws New food label laws from next year will cost businesses tens of millions of dollars but certain producers will be exempt. Vision courtesy ABC News Up Next Nike to cut 1,400 jobs Play Video Don't Play Video duration 01:06 Video duration 01:06 Nike to cut 1,400 jobs Nike to cut 1,400 jobs Nike will cut about two percent of its global workforce as it changes its organisational structure and reduces number of shoe styles. Up Next Mexican-US beer mocks Trump Play Video Don't Play Video duration 01:06 Video duration 01:06 Mexican-US beer mocks Trump Mexican-US beer mocks Trump A cross border team has brewed a new beer featuring President Donald Trump as a gun-slinging mariachi musician. More videos This week all eyes are on Janet Yellen As we go into a new week, the focus will be back on the US Federal Reserve. (This video was produced in commercial partnership between Fairfax Media and IG Markets). 2. ASX: As a lead in for Australia, we can see that while tech has found buyers (which won't wholly affect us), however, financials (+0.44%) and materials (+1.3%) have also performed well and that should support the ASX 200 on open. How the market trades for the rest of the day is obviously not yet known but had you told me at the start of the day yesterday that the financial sector was going to put 49 points into the index and REITS 11 points, I wouldn't have believed you. Either way, we will be looking for further flows into this move, while healthcare has been a sector I've been bullish on and the ASX 200 healthcare sector is a mere 1.2% from a new all-time high. This is where we are seeing the outperformance and the momentum trade working well in Australia. 3. Still some headwinds: Aggregating all the overnight news and we are expecting the market to build on yesterday's gains, specifically in the ASX 200. There are some headwinds however, with spot iron ore down 2.8%, while in the Dalian futures exchange iron ore, steel and coking coal futures were sold off 2.3%, 0.9% and 0.7% respectively. US crude has traded in a range of $46.57 to $45.56 and was providing us some hope that energy stocks were going to find buyers on open, but we have seen a fairly bearish read on the weekly API oil inventory report (at 06:30 aest), with US crude and gasoline inventories increasing 2.8 million and 1.8 million barrels respectively. Consider the analysts were looking for a 2.3 million barrels drawdown in crude inventories in the official Department of Energy report (out at 00:30 aest) and the market is now somewhat positioned for a bearish surprise when the DoE release its statistics. Recall, last week's API was actually a terrible pre-cursor so I wouldn't read too much into it. 4. FX: In FX markets the USD index has dropped a touch, with the CAD continuing to be the strong performer, with USD/CAD hitting a low of $1.3211. Keep an eye on the daily chart of USD/CAD as the pair is finding buyers at the April pivot low and may retrace some lost ground here. Saying that, a close below this level and we should see an extension of this bearish trend into $1.3000. USD/JPY is the natural proxy of all things Federal Reserve and that pair has traded in a tight range of ¥110.27 to ¥109.83 on the session. This tight range in USD/JPY is thematic of such limited moves in US fixed income, across the yield curve and again fixed income will be the purest read of the Fed meeting tonight and I would be paying most close attention to the US five-year treasury over the coming 24 hours given its sensitive to the economic projections and potential views of longer term fed funds rate. The 'real' (or inflation adjusted) five-year rate will also be keenly watched, as this seems to be having a strong bearing on overall financial conditions and a sharp drop in real yields post FOMC (at 04:00 aest) and Janet Yellen's testimony shortly after, will likely be a strong catalyst for gold, emerging market assets and the FANG baskets. Of course, if we see real yields pushing higher it would represent a tightening of financial conditions, which is kind of what you would expect when a central bank raises rates. That could weigh on the S&P 500. 5. Fed non-event: That being said, the market isn't even really interested in the fact the Fed will hike the fed funds rate tonight, it's fully baked in. It's really all about the interest rate curve into 2018, 2019 and even 2020. So it's an exercise in understanding what priced in, or what could be said is not priced in. If we take the fed fund future (a tradeable interest rate instrument) we can see the yield here sitting a 1.555% on the January 2019 contract and 1.745% January 2020. This effectively details 64.5 basis points (or 2.5) and 83.5bp (3.3) of hikes priced in through to the end of 2018 and end of 2019. Contrast this to the Fed's so-called 'dot plot' tonight and there will be much focus on the divergence here. Rates traders will also be following narrative around potential normalisation of the Fed's $4.46 billion balance most intently, where I feel this will start of fall around the October meeting. Advertisement 6. US data: I also think it the market will be fairly sensitive to the US May CPI figures released at 22:30 aest, with the market expecting core inflation at 1.9% annualised. Naturally, this will be superseded by the Fed meeting, but the Fed will be not like the dynamic of extremely accommodative financial conditions, amid falling inflation and subdued inflation expectations. 7. Europe: A recovery in tech stocks and fresh optimism over troubled Italians banks lifted European shares from seven-week lows on Tuesday. Capita led the gains after offering a reassuring outlook. The pan-European STOXX 600 index ended up 0.6 per cent, almost fully recovering losses from the previous session. Italy's benchmark rose 0.9 per cent. 8. Market watch: SPI futures +0.2%, 10 points, to 5792 points AUD -0.04% to US75.38¢ On Wall St, Dow Jones +0.4%, S&P500 +0.4%, Nasdaq +0.8% In Europe, Stoxx 50 +0.4%, FTSE100 -0.2%, CAC40 +0.4%, DAX +0.6% Spot gold +0.7% to $US1266.72 an ounce Brent crude +1.03% to $US48.79 a barrel Iron ore -2.8% to $US53.36 a tonne   This column was produced in commercial partnership    between Fairfax Media Will Microsoft ever be as 'cool' as Apple? By Cale Hunt Tuesday, Jun 13, 2017 at 10:31 am EDT Will Microsoft ever be able to compete with Apple when it comes to "cool factor?" This can be a controversial question. Microsoft is making great strides in the hardware and software departments, and its new devices, including the Surface Laptop and Surface Pro, are constantly compared to Apple hardware. Why? Apple has a certain "cool factor" that many of its loyal fans can't get enough of. Remember those old commercials with Justin Long and John Hodgman, where the stuffy businessman was a PC? Those are partly to blame. Forum member Fahmi Bassem recently started a thread to ask the question of whether or not Microsoft will ever have the same cool factor as Apple, and there are already a bunch of thoughtful replies. FAHMI BASSEM 06-05-2017 02:59 PM “ Twitter if filled with apple stuff before during and after its events, apple related hashtags are at the most popular on twitter (more than 5 #)!!! 136128 Reply Fahmi Bassem points out that Apple-related hashtags are all over Twitter these days, especially during their WWDC 2017 conference. Microsoft hashtags? Not so much. Do you think Microsoft will ever hit the same level of "cool" as Apple? What will it take to reach that level? Head over to our forum now and speak your mind! printed June 16, 2017 See this page online at: http://www.phonescoop.com/articles/article.php?a=19216 ≡ Reviews Phones Phone Finder News Carriers OSes Glossary Register Log In Advertising Licensing About Contact Privacy Terms of Use Home  ›  News  › iOS 10.3.3 Reaches Third Beta Article Comments   Tuesday, 12:55 PM   by Eric M. Zeman   @phonescooper Apple today released a new beta build of iOS 10 for developers. iOS 10.3.3 beta 3, which developers can download over the air, is a minor, bug-fixing release. Apple hasn't provided any details about what's contained in the new code, nor has it released a version for public beta testers yet. This minor update is likely to be the last for iOS 10 before Apple releases iOS 11. Apple is already beta testing iOS 11 with developers and will soon make a public beta available for general testing. The final version of iOS 11 isn't expected to arrive until September. from Apple Related Apple Releases iOS 10 Developer Beta 2 Apple today made a second beta version of iOS 10 available to developers. According to Apple, the new beta contains bug fixes and other improvements. Apple Pushes iOS 10.3.3 to Developers Apple this week released a new beta build of iOS 10 for developers. iOS 10.3.3, which developers can download over the air, is a minor, bug-fixing release. Apple Drops First Beta of iOS 10.3.2 Apple today made iOS 10.3.2 Beta One available to developers. The beta arrives just one day after the public release of iOS 10.3. Apple Releases iOS 10.1 Beta 5 for Devs and Public Testers Apple today made iOS 10.1 Beta 5 available to registered developers and public beta testers alike. This fifth beta follows the release of the fourth beta by just two days, implying that some urgent bug fixes may be contained within. Apple Releases iOS 10 Betas for Developers and Public Testers Apple today released iOS 10 Developer Beta 6 and iOS 10 Public Beta 5, fresh builds of the pre-release operating system for iPhones, iPads, and iPods. The release notes suggest the update contains only bug fixes and other unspecified improvements. more news about:   AD Comments Start a new discussion You must log in to post. Sorry to burst your bubble, but Microsoft's 'Ms Pac-Man beating AI' is more Automatic Idiot Disney mulls Mickey Mouse magic material to thwart pirates' 3D scans Verity Stob AWS launches celebrity-spotting-as-a-service: What a time to be alive Swedish school pumps up volume to ease toilet trauma Hyperloop One teases idea of 50-minute London-Edinburgh ride Class clowns literally classless: Harvard axes meme-flinging morons 125 Software Ever wonder why those Apple iPhone updates take so damn long? Turns out Apple execs were testing new file system on you Craig Federighi explains why Apple forced millions of people to wait ages for their phones to update 13 Jun 2017 at 21:41, Kieren McCarthy It's a recurring pain experienced by all iPhone owners: the huge and very slow software updates that require you to plug your phone in and forget about it for 30 minutes. Many have also wondered why the phone feels the need to shut down, start up again, shut down again and start up again before finally letting you get at it. Well, wonder no more. In an on-stage love fest last week between Apple fanboi John Gruber and senior execs Phil Schiller and Craig Federighi, Federighi – SVP of software engineering – revealed that in the iOS 10.1 and/or 10.2 upgrades to its operating system, it caused every device to upgrade to Apple's new APFS (Apple File System), check it, and then roll back to the current HFS+ system. Asked by Gruber just how Apple managed to be so... so great when it comes to its new file system, Federighi revealed (at around 28 mins into the video): "We actually had this process running for earlier iOS updates. When you updated to 10.1 or 10.2 we were trial-migrating your whole file system, consistency checking it, reporting back to us whether the upgrade was 100 per cent clean and then rolling it back." Trust us That would explain why the 10.1 update (issued in October 2016) had people scratching their heads over its massive size – anything up to 1.6GB for the iPhone 7 Plus. It may also explain the widespread problems that people reported with the updates, including it shutting down unexpectedly while still having a 30 per cent charge with the 10.2 update, issued in December 2016. And it likely explains why Apple had to put out a 10.1.1 update just a week after the massive 10.1 update, because people were continuing to report serious problems. Not that Apple let anyone know about using its entire installed based as guinea pigs – and there is no mention of changing or testing the new file system in Apple's upgrade notes for either 10.1 or 10.2. APFS was finally introduced in iOS update 10.3 at the end of March, three months after the 10.2 updates and five months after Apple first started experimenting on people's phones. Users reported surprise at the fact that it freed up around 10 per cent of the phone storage space as well as increased its overall capacity by around five per cent. Of course, this being Gruber and a theater full of Apple fanbois, Federighi's explanation for why millions of people had to suffer enormous and slow updates as well as phone problems was met with... lots of whooping and a round of applause. Amazing. ® Tips and corrections 125 Comments MORE Apple Smartphones Ios Sign up to our Newsletter Get IT in your inbox daily Subscribe More from The Register Apple finally teaches Android music app to validate certificates Cupertino's so keen on Android it took eight months to repair interception bug 3 Comments Apple fights off iTunes patent spat appeal That bit where you said we didn't have to give them $500m – stick with that 7 Comments Apple blocks comms-snooping malware Leaked developer certificate revoked, protection updated 13 Comments Nokia, Apple lawyers make peace over nasty IP wrangle Unspecified lump sum heading for Finland 24 Comments Apple asks FCC to let it run mm-wave tests - for backhaul?! No, Apple is not practicing to be carrier. Navigation Menu Film TV Digital Music Contenders Video Dirt Scene More Biz Legit Jobs Conferences Insight Archives Directory Choose Edition: U.S Global Asia Russia | My Account Sign In Subscribe Home Digital News NPR One App Launches on Apple TV, NPR Cooperating Closely With Apple on HomePod Janko Roettgers Senior Silicon Valley Correspondent @jank0 Share This Article LinkedIn Email Print Talk Courtesy of Apple June 13, 2017 | 02:15PM PT NPR officially announced the launch of its NPR One app on the latest-generation Apple TV Tuesday, giving users another way to access news, podcasts and live streams from the public broadcast network and its local stations. NPR Chief Digital Officer Tom Hjelm also told Variety that the broadcaster is working closely with Apple to bring public radio to the company’s HomePod smart speaker. NPR launched NPR One about three years ago as a way to make its programming available on demand on mobile devices. Since then, NPR has added podcasts and live streams from local NPR stations, and brought the app to additional platforms, including Chromecast, Fire TV, Amazon Echo and Google Home. Related Apple Announces Smart Home Audio Speaker HomePod The new Apple TV app, which was developed by  Bottle Rocket in cooperation with NPR, now makes the same programming available on 4th-generation Apple TV devices. “It’s another weapon in our arsenal,” said Hjelm. Next up will be an integration into Apple’s HomePod, which the computer maker already teased on stage at its WWDC conference earlier this month. “We will be working closely with Apple,” Hjelm said. He went on to argue that voice-activated speakers represent a great opportunity for public radio. “Screen-less experiences — that’s kind of our DNA.” Hjelm said that listening from smart speakers is still dwarfed by the volume that NPR sees from mobile devices, but argued that there is a lot of potential for these kinds of devices. “We are very, very bullish about this space.”   Filed Under: Apple Tv HomePod NPR Want to read more articles like this one? Subscribe ▲ Learn more about Macworld's Digital Edition    🔎 Home News Reviews How-To Video Macs iPhone/iPad iPhone iPad iOS OS X iOS Apps Accessories Business Entertainment Subscribe Resources Macs MacBooks Mac Desktops iPhones Blogs iPads Accessories Apps Audio Business Cameras Components Development Software Displays E-readers Home Theater iOS iPhone Accessories iPad Accessories iPods OS X Printers Networking Productivity Software Smartwatches Storage Styluses iPhone iPad iOS Home iOS How-To 5 things to do before giving an old iPhone or iPad to your kid Don't hand over an aging iOS device to your eager youngster before doing a little kid-proofing first. Email a friend To Use commas to separate multiple email addresses From Privacy Policy Thank you Your message has been sent. Sorry There was an error emailing this page. By Ben Patterson PCWorld | Jun 9, 2017 6:00 AM PT Credit: Ben Patterson / IDG More like this 4 easy ways to keep your iCloud password safe Configuring an old iPad for your child 6 ways to lock down your iPhone’s lock screen Video iOS 11: The top features announced Like it or not, little kids love iPhones and iPads. They love to look at them, they love to tap and swipe the screen, they love playing iPhone games, and most of all, they love watching videos on them. (“Curious George” is my daughter’s favorite—for this week at least.) Giving your little ones a hand-me-down iOS device is an easy way to satisfy their desire for a screen of their own—my kid is the proud owner of an iPhone 3GS and a third-generation iPad. That said, you shouldn’t hand over your old iPhone or iPad without doing some kid-proofing first. Read on for five ways to prep an aging iPhone or iPad for your youngster, from wiping your data and setting up a child’s iCloud account to blocking web access and keeping her from racking up in-app charges on your credit card. Wipe your old data Before you hand over your old iPhone to your kids, you’ll want to make sure any and all of your personal data has been wiped clean. The best way to do so is to perform a “factory” reset, which wipes the iPhone’s storage and returns it to its factory settings. Ben Patterson / IDG Make sure to back up and then wipe your data before handing over your old iPhone to your child. Naturally, you should first make sure you’ve backed up any old iPhone or iPad data you want to preserve. You may already have taken care of this step if you’ve previously upgraded to a new iPhone or iPad and restored your data from iCloud. If not, tap Settings, tap your iCloud profile, then tap iCloud > Backup > Back Up Now. You can also back up your old iPhone or iPad by connecting it to your Mac or PC and syncing it with iTunes. Once you’re satisfied that your data is safe and sound, go ahead and wipe the device. Tap Settings > General > Reset > Erase All Content and Settings. Once the reset is complete, your old iPhone or iPad will return to its factory settings, just like the day it came out of the box. Create a child’s iCloud account While it may seem a little soon to, say, create an Apple ID for a toddler, take it from me: it won’t be long before your onesie-clad cutie is walking, talking and pleading for an iPhone upgrade—and when that happens, it’ll be easier to migrate her data and apps if she already has her own iCloud account. Ben Patterson / IDG Just because your child is under 13 doesn’t mean she can’t have her own iCloud account and Apple ID. Even if your kid is younger than 13 years old, she can still have her own iCloud account and Apple ID. All you need to do is create the account under iOS’s “Family Sharing” umbrella. With her iCloud account, your child will be able to sign in to an old iPhone or iPad, download apps, and even purchase items from the App Store—only with your approval, of course. Also, keep in mind that just because she has an iCloud account, your daughter or son won’t be able to start web surfing, tweeting, or posting selfies on Instagram without your say-so. (More on iOS’s parental controls in a moment.) You can create a child’s iCloud account directly on your own iPhone or iPad. Just tap Settings, tap your iCloud username, then tap Family Sharing > Add Family Member > Create an Apple ID for a child. You’ll need to enter your kid’s birthday, agree to some disclosures and legalese, choose a payment method for App Store purchases (which, again, you can control and/or block), then choose an Apple ID username and password. By default, your kid’s new iCloud account won’t let her make App Store purchases without your consent. To double-check the “Ask to Buy” setting, tap Settings, tap your iCloud account name, then tap Family Sharing and your kid’s name. Control what your kid can—and can’t—do on her iPhone or iPad Once you’ve got your old iPhone or iPad set up with your child’s new iCloud account, it’s time to make some decisions on which iOS features will be fair game for your kid, and which will be off-limits. Ben Patterson / IDG Don’t want your child surfing the web or snapping photos on her hand-me-down iPhone? You can block those activities in iOS’s Restrictions settings. Tap Settings > General > Restrictions > Enable Restrictions, then create a Restrictions passcode. Next, scroll down and disable all the iOS features that you’d rather your kid not mess with. You’ll probably want to disable Safari and the iTunes store right away. You may also want to block your child from installing apps, and if you don’t want your little one snapping a million photos of their crib, you might want to nix the Camera app, too. In the “Allowed Content” section, make sure to disable in-app purchases, as well as block music with explicit music and any grown-up movies, TV shows and books. In the Privacy section, you can control which apps can access location services, contacts, the microphone, and more on your kid’s iPhone. At the bottom of the Restrictions screen, you can also disable access to multiplayer games, friend adding, and screen recording for any Game Center-ready games. Hide Settings, Mail, and other Apple apps Even after you’ve thoroughly managed all of iOS’s Restrictions settings, you may still see some home-screen icons on your kid’s iPhone or iPad that you’d rather she not mess with. For example, the Settings icon should probably stay out of her hands, as well as the Mail app, Game Center, and the App Store. Ben Patterson / IDG You can hide the Mail, App Store, and other Apple apps in a folder, preferably on its own home screen in the back. Here’s what I did before I gave my daughter my old iPhone: I hid all those various Apple apps in a “Hidden” folder in the very last iOS home screen. To create a home screen folder, drag one app icon on top of another, name the folder, then start dragging other app icons into the newly created folder. Naturally, older kids who are a bit more iOS savvy may quickly sniff out the “Hidden” folder. My five-year-old, for example, knows exactly where I’ve tucked away the Settings icon, but she doesn’t really care—probably because tapping Settings won’t get her any closer to Curious George. Turn on Airplane mode One way to make sure your little one doesn’t wander into a grown-up corner of the Internet on her iPhone is to cut off Internet access altogether, and the easiest way to do that is to turn on Airplane mode. (Of course, you can kiss Airplane mode goodbye once your children start clamoring for the streaming PBS Kids video app, which they’ll do once they hit about 3 or so.) Just tap Settings, then flip on the Airplane Mode switch. Ben Patterson / IDG Turning on Airplane mode is an easy way to keep tiny iPhone users off the Internet. If your old iPhone or iPad is running on iOS 6 or later, you may also want to disable home-screen and in-app access to Control Center, the flip-up control panel that includes an Airplane Mode button, To do so, tap Settings > Control Center, then switch off the Access on Lock Screen and Access Within Apps settings. That won’t completely disable Control Center, but at least it’ll make it a tad more challenging to find. This story, "5 things to do before giving an old iPhone or iPad to your kid" was originally published by PCWorld. To comment on this article and other Macworld content, visit our Facebook page or our Twitter feed. Digital Trends Home > Deals > Great deal! These are our three favorite Amazon… Great deal! These are our three favorite Amazon tech bargains today By Kara Kamenec — Updated June 13, 2017 10:40 am Share Why have 1 room when you can have 2? Our favorite transforming homes The 50 best NES games of all time Get today's popular Digital Trends articles in your inbox: Tuesday’s Amazon Gold Box Deals feature a smart headband that helps you meditate, a set of Apple-certified earbuds, and a surge protector charging station. Score savings up to $110 and discounts as deep as 79 percent. Read on to browse today’s best Amazon tech deals. Muse: The Brain-Sensing Headband Improve your mental well-being with the help of tech with Muse: The Brain-Sensing Headband, which is currently 20 percent off on Amazon. The smart headband acts as your personal meditation assistant andalso measures your brain activity. The headband is the first tool that gives you accurate, real-time feedback on what’s happening in your brain when you meditate. Using Muse, you can improve your brain function in as little as 3 minutes a day while experiencing the benefits of meditation, which include relaxation, improved mood, and reduced stress. The device provides personalized tracking, motivational challenges, and rewards to encourage you to build a more regular and effective practice. Similar to how a heart monitor measures your pulse, Muse uses the same brain-sensing technology that doctors and scientists have employed for more than a century to detect your brain signals. It has seven finely calibrated sensors – two on the forehead, two behind the ears, and three reference sensors – which detect and measure the activity of your brain. The headband measures whether your mind is calm or active, and translates that data into weather sounds — either calm or more intense — to help you stay in a peaceful state of mind. Muse: The Brain-Sensing Headband normally retails for $250 but is currently on sale for $200 on Amazon, saving you $50 (20 percent).
