Google hires ex-Apple chipset veteran to help design SoCs for Pixel phones Ryne Hager Follow View All Posts 2017/06/13 11:36am PDTJun 13, 2017 46 Plus 1 on G+ 195 Share on Facebook 52 Share on Twitter Total Shares293 Google News Google's hardware plans for the future are getting bigger. Variety is reporting that Google has hired Manu Gulati, a hardware architect, away from Apple. Gulati is reported as having previously played a significant role in the development of Apple's SoCs for the last eight years and was hired sometime in the last few weeks. His new title at Google is Lead SOC Architect, and he's expected to work on custom chipsets for future Pixel phones. If Manu Gulati can apply the same black magic to Google's future products as he did on Apple's custom chips, things could be fantastic. Apple's "A" series chips are amazing pieces of hardware. Though Apple does license ARM's tech, unlike other manufacturers, they don't just toss the licensed reference designs on a wafer. Apple has bent over backward to optimize their silicon architecture for iOS, and the resulting performance on Apple devices definitely demonstrates that. Although some Android chipset vendors, such as Qualcomm, do make custom designs like the Kryo, for whatever reason Apple's custom hardware (combined with their software) has held an edge in performance for years. For most of us, any advantage the A series chips have doesn't make any difference without the Android operating system. But if Google is able to bring the same degree of performance enhancements and customization over into their future hardware, the future of Android SoC performance could be bright. After the dark and regressive ages of the Snapdragon 808/810 and Qualcomm's rushed 64bit development cycle, I would like nothing more than to see Google bring a first party chipset in a future Pixel device. And who knows, they might even sell it to other manufacturers, increasing competition in the currently stagnant mobile chipset space. Gulati joining Google finally lends credence to the old stories of Google's interest in SoC designing. And it appears to be full steam ahead, as supplemental job postings for SoC design have appeared on Google Careers. Whether these efforts result in a new custom chipset by Google, or we just see some new specialized hardware for machine learning, either way, things should be interesting. Source: Linkedin Via: Variety Tags apple ARM chipset hardware SoC subscribe ... Previous Story [Lame] Netflix places limits on how many times you can download certain content ... Next Story Google adds more Local Guides levels and ways to earn points Trending 252 Exclusive: Nova Launcher finally gets Google Now integration [APK Download] 2017/06/14 9:16am PDTJun 14, 2017 468 Exclusive: This is the OnePlus 5 2017/06/06 11:24am PDTJun 6, 2017 14 [Deal Alert] edjing Pro, normally $4.99, is temporarily free 2017/05/17 2:38am PDTMay 17, 2017 Comments Renan That would be amazing. Now Google just needs to start selling Pixel devices in South America (or specifically in Brazil). Leonardo Loures Quirino Amém! Renan Hehe. I knew more brazilians wanted Google's stuff. Yoshi Everyone here wants it, bro. Look at all the people wishing the good times of Galaxy Nexus, Nexus 4 and 5 selling in almost every good store. Renan I know. I'm one of these people, lol Lucas de Eiroz ™ Google Pixel, Google Store, Android Pay (and Google Wallet), and all Google services! Renan I'm dying for Android Pay! Random! They'd better reduce their prices first by at least 50% Renan That would be a dream, too. Ricardo Ferreira If they are priced like Moto/Lenovo is, it should be a blessing. Take the Moto G5 for example and you'll see that our price isn't that far off. Freek Smulders This could be yuge! Lord Argyris Bigly big league! Duder12 HUGE kabiluddin Guess we'll see the new custom soc in late 2018/9 Honestly can't wait. destinyhud pixel 3 then!!! Godspoken I recall "Google silicon" being referenced last year as a future goal of the Pixel, very exciting. blackice85 Isn't that one of the things holding them back from providing updates for longer periods of time too? Could be a big deal not just for the performance gains. Gregory That Project Treble thing or how do you call it in O is also all about cutting on dependencies from third parties like Qualcomm. blackice85 Oh I hadn't heard about that, I bet this is one aspect of it then. Duder12 Project Treble doesnt improve years of update support. It brings updates faster since Qualcomm and OEMs can work on software updates at the same time. Qualcomm can still decide to not ship new drivers for old versions of Android just like they always have. Google doing their own SOC is the only real answer Gregory From my understanding, it eliminates the need for the drivers to be updated in the first place. someone755 You can't expect to not update drivers with new Android versions. Say there's an Android system API that a driver adheres to. As something banal, let's say we have a driver that controls whether the hardware button backlight is on or off, and that the system can control whether it is either on or off. Then a newer Android version appears which supports both the old API but also a newer one, wherein the hardware backlight can be controlled as if it were analog (from 0-255 for example). Then, the third system version comes out that ditches support for the old API and only still supports the newer one. Yes the OEM could hack things up so that values 0-254 would mean the light is off and then 255 would mean it's on, but this further complicates both the user experience and app compatibility as well as future system version compatibility. At this point if you want a stable and future-proof software solution, you absolutely have to update the driver to support the new API. And if the backlight vendor can't provide one, then it's more trouble than it's worth for the OEM to do the hack themselves and they just post a note online saying your device won't get upgraded, leaving you with no choice but to either resort to community hacks or buy a new device. Yes the example is completely idiotic but it serves as an example of why you can't go around updating devices without driver updates. Aside from the functionality aspect there are many security flaws that could affect a driver. And not updating that huge gaping hole in your security while providing monthly 'security patches' that claim to solve security threats is just inane. At that point why even bother with security patches if you can't expect chipset vendors to fix the problems in their closed-source firmware, or hold them accountable for it. Gregory While I completely understand your point, I'd like to extend it to say that there could be such a backlight that can be either on or off, and it's a hardware limitation, so it isn't possible to fully implement the new API on that device. I mean, hardware configurations vary, it's a matter of fact. The point of HAL (hardware abstraction layer) is to abstract away the differences across the underlying hardware, and provide a unified API for the system services to interact with said hardware. If the HAL doesn't provide support for some new feature that was added in a system update but the hardware could technically support it, it still means that the system would behave as though that feature isn't supported by the hardware, and that's it. I'd rather have a device that doesn't support that new feature than a device that is no longer updated. And security... How about people ALWAYS check for buffer boundaries before copying memory? What do they do with all that time and disk space they save? Or, at least, if they're that lazy, run a static analyzer on your code and fix whatever it finds. And run it in valgrind to find memory leaks. It's not that hard to write vulnerability-free code from the start. someone755 But a device will never pass certification, either by Google or an FCC-like entity or another office, with broken features. This is exactly why the 8974 line got dropped -- the hardware didn't support a feature that Google wanted so they didn't let any 8974 device pass CTS. How do you think people running Nougat just fine on their hammerheads (via one custom ROM or another) feel about this conundrum when they've been cut short an entire system update because of Google's insane chip requirements? It's easy to know how to prevent bad code but often times projects start simple and private and unoptimized, and then grow into something much larger that's hard to maintain. A classic example is Android itself (look at all the memory leaks that L introduced). Gregory Well... If a device passed certification by Google (CTS) and carriers, that feature was optional from the beginning, right? Android does already support a plethora of different hardware configurations with different capabilities. If a device didn't have some feature at launch, I don't expect it to have that feature enabled with a software update. CTS is about keeping compatibility with apps (it tests public APIs), it has nothing to do with drivers and hardware. There are literally no hardware requirements that make it impossible to update existing devices more than a year or two. Carrier certification is about device interfacing correctly with carrier equipment, it did so well when it was released and certified, so just don't touch the modem firmware because it's already doing its job good enough, as simple as that. There are exactly zero reasons to modify the HAL for system updates provided HAL and the rest of the system are properly separated, which, from my understanding, they are with Project Treble. It also adds CTS-like standardized test suite for these things. What the hell is 8974? someone755 Msm8974. The Snapdragon 800 platform that phones like the N5, Z3, G2, S5, M8 etc were based on. That got blocked from receiving any sort of updates because Google decided that Vulkan or GL 3.1 was necessary for the upgrade. Not that modern low-end phones are capable of performing the task that the requirement was set for anyways. Basically the thing my entire argument is set around but alright... Owais Lone > Qualcomm can still decide to not ship new drivers for old versions of Android just like they always have. ... and Project Treble will enable device vendors to still ship updates in this exact case. Project Treble cuts out qualcom and SoC manufacturers out of the update cycle. The device vendors will be bottleneck and decision makers now. someone755 This is incorrect. Please see my reply to Gregory above. Owais Lone Your example exactly illustrates the problem now. Project Treble is supposed to abstract these internal hardware level ABIs/APIs so vendors don't have to re-implement the whole layer again. Only time when SOC vendors will have to update their code is when Project Treble itself comes out with a breaking change and a major version upgrade. Of course, vendors might have to or want to make changes here and there but the abstraction should save them from re-doing all of it on every update and if the vendor does not want to improve/optimize with every update, they shouldn't have to make any changes at all unless Treble itself comes out with an incompatible update. someone755 And say that Android P is the one where the button backlight brightness from my example becomes an analog value and the digital on/off API is dropped. Then the phones that incorporate this function will either have to have the driver updated or will not get updated to the next Android version. This is a problem and always will be, as long as chip vendors are not held responsible and held to a higher standard, and as long as the entities that certify devices for daily use (CTS, FCC etc) have some standards themselves (in the sense of not letting devices with broken/missing core features pass). Owais Lone If such a change happens at the HW level, it'll be abstracted at the treble API level so phones that leverage treble API will not need any change at all. Vendors would need to update their code if the change happened in Treble's apI itself which is extremely unlikely as it'll defeat the purpose of having Treble in the first place. That said, there will be major updates to Treble which might break backward compatibility but it's Google's job to keep those changes at a minimal or the whole idea will be worthless. someone755 This is exactly what I'm saying -- if Treble changes (which it most probably will across Android versions, as the system has changed until now), the chip vendors will *have* to provide updates. And there is no way around this limitation, Treble or not, if Google makes some absurd changes then phones won't get updated. Owais Lone Yes, that is true but why would that happen in the first place? That would completely defeat the purpose. Treble will most likely always be backward compatible. It'll probably only add new features and new APIs but not break existing ones. That's how I would handle the project. Sukrith Krishnakumar If I have enough money to buy a pixel by that time I'll surely be skipping the first pixel with this soc! Who knows if SD808/810, LG nucleon or nucleus or whatever it was called happens with this soc as well?! Suicide_Note Your loss. MJ How about you wait for the reviews first before deciding to skip it or not? Sukrith Krishnakumar Even if I have enough money to buy a pixel by that time I'll surely be skipping the first pixel with this soc! Who knows if SD808/810, LG nucleon or nucleus or whatever it was called happens with this soc as well?! TheRunner024 This is great news. How long will it take them to build a SoC? 2 years? Keith Taylor Yep bout that long. destinyhud yeah 2 years. they started this in 2015 so i would guess maybe pixel 3 could have google soc Daniel I've always been a Snapdragon all the way kind of guy, but this would definitely fix updates, give better performance, and bunches of other stuff. I'm a convert. Ditch you Snapdragon. Renan I'm with you. As long as this brings longer support for Google's devices, I'm in. psy spy Always Snapdragon? What choices did you have? Iwanova Nvidia & Mediatek? (I know, Mediatek have no source code, but still. It's mobile SoC right) jesuguru Exynos? Nomaan There was quite a competition until 2012 when we had Snapdragon, Exynos, Tegra, OMAP, NovaThor in the SoC game. Lateef Alabi-Oki Anything to put Qualcomm, with their shitty inefficient power-hungry proprietary insecure SoC drivers, out of our misery is welcome. h4rr4r Please get the drivers in mainline or at least GPLed and into AOSP. MJ I am not as excited (yet) as most of you are about this. I see two possible scenarios coming out of custom chipset from Google... 1.) The main reason Apple's SoC performs better is because it's optimized for iOS and only iOS. It is not properly documented so no other OS can really run it. I would rather stick with a Qualcomm SoC if Google goes down this road. 2.) Google creates a fully open and documented SoC but it performs no better than Apple's or Qualcomm's chips. I would prefer a fully open and documented chipset that can compete as good or better than anything else out there. Possible? I don't know... Regardless, I suspect Google is looking to make some custom hardware for AI or VR first before we see a custom chipset for a phone. Thinker Apple A10x: Single thread 3900 Multi thread 9300 ------------------------- MacBook Pro 2016 intel: Single 3900 Multi 7700 No, Qualcomm S835 is far away from coming close to intel. Thinker Wrong. Anandtech: "The new Kryo 280, despite the similar name, shares no design DNA with the original Kryo. Its an octa-core, big.LITTLE configuration with four “performance” cores and four lower-power “efficiency” cores. What makes Kryo 280 unique, however, is that it’s the first design to use ARM’s new "Built on ARM Cortex Technology" (BoC) license, which allows vendors to customize ARM cores. This new semi-custom option gives vendors the ability to differentiate their products from those using ARM’s stock cores while avoiding the more costly route of creating a fully-custom design from scratch." Again, like I said above, S835 CPU core was a step BACKWARDS. It is basically a generic CPU core with memory controller from Qualcomm. S820 used custom cores but with S835, Qualcomm used generic. Anyone could design a CPU like the A10, only apple does, because only Apple need one like that, it doesnt show genius, or more advanced design, its just different to similarly performing ARM and Intel CPUs. The money for them is up to where OEMs (who make low-end and midrange phones) are willing to pay for the chips -- any higher and they don't have the knowledge/technology/budget to produce something more powerful. Any lower and, well, this is as low as it can go, and the other competitors (Qualcomm, Intel) have worse-performing chips available for the price that MediaTek offers theirs at. Why that is, I have no clue, but I suspect it could have something to do with Qcom having a monopoly on ARM-based chips, and Intel thinking that their overpriced-desktop-chips-with-no-competitor strategy is going to work here, in a highly competitive environment. The point here being that MediaTek works off tight margins and sells in large quantities. Restructuring this process so that it fits our idea of a Qualcomm competitor would be expensive, and definitely riskier than what the payoff is worth to the investor. reggjoo Maybe he can help bring that single core performance up to apple levels. FastCo.Works Studio An award-winning team of journalists, designers, and videographers who tell brand stories through Fast Company’s distinctive lens.Current Issue Current Issue SUBSCRIBE Follow us: advertisement advertisement 06.13.17 Everything You Need To Know About That Apple Watch App For Surfers Mentioned At WWDC Xensr’s Sessions app adds some science to the art of surfing so users can catch the best waves. [Photo: Unsplash user Isai Ramos] By Mark Sullivan4 minute Read During the WWDC keynote last week, Apple announced that the Apple Watch’s next OS (watchOS 4) will allow the device to establish a direct Bluetooth connection to other devices such as blood glucose sensors (for people with diabetes) or smart tennis rackets (yawn). advertisement Or surfboards. Wait. What? Actually, an Apple Watch with a direct connection to a sensor mounted on a surfboard could prove to be a game changer for some surfers. Apple VP Kevin Lynch briefly mentioned an Apple Watch app called Sessions by a small Green Bay, Wisconsin, company called Xensr. The app works with a sensor (the $200 Xensr Air 3D) mounted on the surfboard to capture both wave data and the performance of the surfer. David Troup The GPS radio inside the mounted sensor device, says Xensr founder David Troup, allows it to act as a “wave buoy” that collects all kinds of data about the waves in the area, and can even help forecast future waves. The gyroscope in the device tracks all motions of the surfboard; the number, locations, and sizes of waves surfed; the height of jumps off waves; and the lengths of waves surfed. Until now Xensr users have waited to get back to shore to check out wave and performance data on their phone screen. That’s because the sensor has to sync with a phone to transfer the data. But the new direct Bluetooth support in watchOS 4 will let surfers see the data (in small bits) on their wrist while they’re out on the board, paddling between waves. The data might help a surfer adjust their game in situ to catch more waves and ride them longer. Example: A big part of the art of surfing is sensing the best time—and best location on the curve of the wave—to get up on the board. This is called the takeoff point, and picking the best ones is probably the hardest thing about surfing. The Xensr app might add some science to the art. “It’ll give me a map of all my takeoff points on all my best waves,” Troup told me. That knowledge could inform the choice of takeoff point on future waves. “I may get two or three more turns on that same wave just because of the takeoff point,” Troup says. advertisement Or the app might guide a surfer to better waves. “It might tell me that I need to be a little bit further to the west of where I’ve been surfing,” Troup says. Stephen Baxter, a 37-year-old lifelong surfer who lives in Santa Cruz, California, said the Xensr app could be a useful addition to an Apple Watch user who wants to measure a surf session for fitness, just like athletes measure a run, swim, or bike ride. Baxter says the Xensr/Watch combo can be compared with the Rip Curl Search GPS watch ($400), which shares many of the same features as the Xensr app and comes in a sturdy, purpose-built case. Other products like the Trace sensor ($199) also mount to a surfboard and track similar information such as speed, length of ride, and turn radius. As with the Rip Curl Watch, Trace relays information to a smartphone for review after surfing. “If you own an Apple Watch, and you’re the kind of person who wants that kind of instant info, it could be useful,” Baxter told me. The biggest worry about the Xensr Apple Watch app might be the Watch itself. Surfing presents problems even for conventional watches, Baxter points out. “They often won’t even tell time after exposure to salt, sun, sand, water, and wind–not to mention potential impact with surfboards, rocks, and reefs.” advertisement Assuming your Watch survives, Troup says the Session app will, in the near future, give surfers the benefit of data gathered by other surfers’ Xensrs. This might be especially helpful for surfers who are trying out a spot for the first time. Xensr will also explore a social aspect of the app, which will allow surfers to talk smack among themselves about who owned the gnarliest waves on any given day. You might expect a company like Xensr to operate out of a bungalow in Venice or Malibu, but Xensr hales from Green Bay, Wisconsin. Troup, who holds a degree in artificial intelligence, says he does his surfing (and windsurfing and kitesurfing) on Lake Michigan and Lake Superior. The five-year-old company of seven employees has a “field team” of professional boarders in Maui who test the sensor out on the waves. “About the time we’re finishing our software builds here in Wisconsin–around noon–our people in Maui are getting ready to go out surfing,” Troup said. “So when they come back in for breakfast, they can give us their feedback.” Xensr is funded almost entirely by Troup, with some help from local Midwest investors. He’s been talking to West Coast VCs about a fresh round of capital for the company. The West Coast VCs might be a little more appreciative of Xensr’s virtues than the Midwest firms, Troup believes. He’s right. Because many VC people in California are also surfers. Xensr will release its new Sessions app this month, and Apple will begin updating Apple Watches with watchOS 4 this fall. Check out the latest theme park experiences and attractions Business Technology Good news from Apple conference surprises AMD UCF RESTORES uses virtual reality headsets, scents and sounds to treat post-traumatic stress disorder sufferers to lessen anxiety. UCF RESTORES uses virtual reality headsets, scents and sounds to treat post-traumatic stress disorder sufferers to lessen anxiety. Marco SantanaContact ReporterOrlando Sentinel Privacy Policy The Orlando division of the tech company AMD received a bit of a surprise at Apple’s annual developers’ conference last week. Baked into an announcement that Apple computers would support virtual reality, in both its high-end computers and external plug ins, the company said it would do so with AMD-built hardware. Joe Cox, AMD’s Orlando-based corporate vice president, said the most significant part is that AMD now has a presence in all of Apple’s products. We caught up with Cox shortly after the announcement. How big of a deal is it to have your product in Apple computers? I’m glad we have unseated Nvidia from those Macs. They made a big deal about the power of the Vega. Clearly, this is a move to solidify its presence in virtual reality. Some have knocked VR. How big do you think virtual reality will become? Virtual reality will be around a long time. It’s definitely something that has arrived and is real. But it will take a long time to work out the kinks. Augmented reality might make more sense right now. Archive: UCF helps fight PTSD using virtual reality » Where do we stand right now? There still needs to be a lot of development in virtual reality. We are still in the flat part of the curve right now but it’s an important feature. How can AMD keep itself in the conversation about graphics processors, in the long term? We undergo constant iteration. Like my boss says: “Until it looks real and you can’t discern the difference, you are not done.” We are not worried about running out of work. We are not worried about any kind of pullback. How has Orlando played into that effort? We are known as a center of excellence for visual simulation. The military, that’s where all of this came out of. It’s part of the story. When you talk about it, you have to recognize that. Google hires ex-Apple chipset veteran to help design SoCs for Pixel phones Ryne Hager Follow View All Posts 2017/06/13 11:36am PDTJun 13, 2017 46 Plus 1 on G+ 195 Share on Facebook 52 Share on Twitter Total Shares293 Google News Google's hardware plans for the future are getting bigger. Variety is reporting that Google has hired Manu Gulati, a hardware architect, away from Apple. Gulati is reported as having previously played a significant role in the development of Apple's SoCs for the last eight years and was hired sometime in the last few weeks. His new title at Google is Lead SOC Architect, and he's expected to work on custom chipsets for future Pixel phones. If Manu Gulati can apply the same black magic to Google's future products as he did on Apple's custom chips, things could be fantastic. Apple's "A" series chips are amazing pieces of hardware. Though Apple does license ARM's tech, unlike other manufacturers, they don't just toss the licensed reference designs on a wafer. Apple has bent over backward to optimize their silicon architecture for iOS, and the resulting performance on Apple devices definitely demonstrates that. Although some Android chipset vendors, such as Qualcomm, do make custom designs like the Kryo, for whatever reason Apple's custom hardware (combined with their software) has held an edge in performance for years. For most of us, any advantage the A series chips have doesn't make any difference without the Android operating system. But if Google is able to bring the same degree of performance enhancements and customization over into their future hardware, the future of Android SoC performance could be bright. After the dark and regressive ages of the Snapdragon 808/810 and Qualcomm's rushed 64bit development cycle, I would like nothing more than to see Google bring a first party chipset in a future Pixel device. And who knows, they might even sell it to other manufacturers, increasing competition in the currently stagnant mobile chipset space. Gulati joining Google finally lends credence to the old stories of Google's interest in SoC designing. And it appears to be full steam ahead, as supplemental job postings for SoC design have appeared on Google Careers. Whether these efforts result in a new custom chipset by Google, or we just see some new specialized hardware for machine learning, either way, things should be interesting. Source: Linkedin Via: Variety Tags apple ARM chipset hardware SoC subscribe ... Previous Story [Lame] Netflix places limits on how many times you can download certain content ... Duder12 HUGE kabiluddin Guess we'll see the new custom soc in late 2018/9 Honestly can't wait. destinyhud pixel 3 then!!! Godspoken I recall "Google silicon" being referenced last year as a future goal of the Pixel, very exciting. blackice85 Isn't that one of the things holding them back from providing updates for longer periods of time too? Could be a big deal not just for the performance gains. Gregory That Project Treble thing or how do you call it in O is also all about cutting on dependencies from third parties like Qualcomm. blackice85 Oh I hadn't heard about that, I bet this is one aspect of it then. Duder12 Project Treble doesnt improve years of update support. It brings updates faster since Qualcomm and OEMs can work on software updates at the same time. Qualcomm can still decide to not ship new drivers for old versions of Android just like they always have. Google doing their own SOC is the only real answer Gregory From my understanding, it eliminates the need for the drivers to be updated in the first place. someone755 You can't expect to not update drivers with new Android versions. Say there's an Android system API that a driver adheres to. As something banal, let's say we have a driver that controls whether the hardware button backlight is on or off, and that the system can control whether it is either on or off. Then a newer Android version appears which supports both the old API but also a newer one, wherein the hardware backlight can be controlled as if it were analog (from 0-255 for example). Then, the third system version comes out that ditches support for the old API and only still supports the newer one. Yes the OEM could hack things up so that values 0-254 would mean the light is off and then 255 would mean it's on, but this further complicates both the user experience and app compatibility as well as future system version compatibility. At this point if you want a stable and future-proof software solution, you absolutely have to update the driver to support the new API. And if the backlight vendor can't provide one, then it's more trouble than it's worth for the OEM to do the hack themselves and they just post a note online saying your device won't get upgraded, leaving you with no choice but to either resort to community hacks or buy a new device. Yes the example is completely idiotic but it serves as an example of why you can't go around updating devices without driver updates. Aside from the functionality aspect there are many security flaws that could affect a driver. And not updating that huge gaping hole in your security while providing monthly 'security patches' that claim to solve security threats is just inane. At that point why even bother with security patches if you can't expect chipset vendors to fix the problems in their closed-source firmware, or hold them accountable for it. Gregory While I completely understand your point, I'd like to extend it to say that there could be such a backlight that can be either on or off, and it's a hardware limitation, so it isn't possible to fully implement the new API on that device. I mean, hardware configurations vary, it's a matter of fact. The point of HAL (hardware abstraction layer) is to abstract away the differences across the underlying hardware, and provide a unified API for the system services to interact with said hardware. If the HAL doesn't provide support for some new feature that was added in a system update but the hardware could technically support it, it still means that the system would behave as though that feature isn't supported by the hardware, and that's it. I'd rather have a device that doesn't support that new feature than a device that is no longer updated. And security... How about people ALWAYS check for buffer boundaries before copying memory? What do they do with all that time and disk space they save? Or, at least, if they're that lazy, run a static analyzer on your code and fix whatever it finds. And run it in valgrind to find memory leaks. It's not that hard to write vulnerability-free code from the start. someone755 But a device will never pass certification, either by Google or an FCC-like entity or another office, with broken features. This is exactly why the 8974 line got dropped -- the hardware didn't support a feature that Google wanted so they didn't let any 8974 device pass CTS. How do you think people running Nougat just fine on their hammerheads (via one custom ROM or another) feel about this conundrum when they've been cut short an entire system update because of Google's insane chip requirements? It's easy to know how to prevent bad code but often times projects start simple and private and unoptimized, and then grow into something much larger that's hard to maintain. A classic example is Android itself (look at all the memory leaks that L introduced). Gregory Well... If a device passed certification by Google (CTS) and carriers, that feature was optional from the beginning, right? Android does already support a plethora of different hardware configurations with different capabilities. If a device didn't have some feature at launch, I don't expect it to have that feature enabled with a software update. CTS is about keeping compatibility with apps (it tests public APIs), it has nothing to do with drivers and hardware. There are literally no hardware requirements that make it impossible to update existing devices more than a year or two. Carrier certification is about device interfacing correctly with carrier equipment, it did so well when it was released and certified, so just don't touch the modem firmware because it's already doing its job good enough, as simple as that. There are exactly zero reasons to modify the HAL for system updates provided HAL and the rest of the system are properly separated, which, from my understanding, they are with Project Treble. It also adds CTS-like standardized test suite for these things. What the hell is 8974? someone755 Msm8974. The Snapdragon 800 platform that phones like the N5, Z3, G2, S5, M8 etc were based on. That got blocked from receiving any sort of updates because Google decided that Vulkan or GL 3.1 was necessary for the upgrade. Not that modern low-end phones are capable of performing the task that the requirement was set for anyways. Basically the thing my entire argument is set around but alright... Owais Lone > Qualcomm can still decide to not ship new drivers for old versions of Android just like they always have. ... and Project Treble will enable device vendors to still ship updates in this exact case. Project Treble cuts out qualcom and SoC manufacturers out of the update cycle. The device vendors will be bottleneck and decision makers now. someone755 This is incorrect. Please see my reply to Gregory above. Owais Lone Your example exactly illustrates the problem now. Project Treble is supposed to abstract these internal hardware level ABIs/APIs so vendors don't have to re-implement the whole layer again. Only time when SOC vendors will have to update their code is when Project Treble itself comes out with a breaking change and a major version upgrade. Of course, vendors might have to or want to make changes here and there but the abstraction should save them from re-doing all of it on every update and if the vendor does not want to improve/optimize with every update, they shouldn't have to make any changes at all unless Treble itself comes out with an incompatible update. someone755 And say that Android P is the one where the button backlight brightness from my example becomes an analog value and the digital on/off API is dropped. Then the phones that incorporate this function will either have to have the driver updated or will not get updated to the next Android version. This is a problem and always will be, as long as chip vendors are not held responsible and held to a higher standard, and as long as the entities that certify devices for daily use (CTS, FCC etc) have some standards themselves (in the sense of not letting devices with broken/missing core features pass). Owais Lone If such a change happens at the HW level, it'll be abstracted at the treble API level so phones that leverage treble API will not need any change at all. Vendors would need to update their code if the change happened in Treble's apI itself which is extremely unlikely as it'll defeat the purpose of having Treble in the first place. That said, there will be major updates to Treble which might break backward compatibility but it's Google's job to keep those changes at a minimal or the whole idea will be worthless. someone755 This is exactly what I'm saying -- if Treble changes (which it most probably will across Android versions, as the system has changed until now), the chip vendors will *have* to provide updates. And there is no way around this limitation, Treble or not, if Google makes some absurd changes then phones won't get updated. Owais Lone Yes, that is true but why would that happen in the first place? That would completely defeat the purpose. Treble will most likely always be backward compatible. It'll probably only add new features and new APIs but not break existing ones. That's how I would handle the project. One core would be almost always in use for background tasks, and as such would burn through battery. Android is not that dissimilar, it has far more background activity than iOS, and therefore needs less powerful, more numerous cores that use less power. The trick is making all those cores useful when you need to run a single powerful task. This is something that Android has got much better at, but it doesnt really show up well in benchmarks. Thinker Wrong. Anandtech: "The new Kryo 280, despite the similar name, shares no design DNA with the original Kryo. Its an octa-core, big.LITTLE configuration with four “performance” cores and four lower-power “efficiency” cores. What makes Kryo 280 unique, however, is that it’s the first design to use ARM’s new "Built on ARM Cortex Technology" (BoC) license, which allows vendors to customize ARM cores. This new semi-custom option gives vendors the ability to differentiate their products from those using ARM’s stock cores while avoiding the more costly route of creating a fully-custom design from scratch." Again, like I said above, S835 CPU core was a step BACKWARDS. It is basically a generic CPU core with memory controller from Qualcomm. S820 used custom cores but with S835, Qualcomm used generic. Again, you never answered my other question. How many instruction set per cycle can A10 do vs S835? STFU dude. You are ignorant. Just_No_Stop You realise that a SoC isnt just the cores right? The memory controller and GPU are what make the 835 custom. If the 835 and the Exynos are generic then why is the Exynos faster despite a lower clock? Again, you lack understanding, all you can do is regurgitate rubbish you have read on a website. Exynos is almost entirely ARM reference, the 835 is not, generic cores maybe, but otherwise completely custom. Sadly all that customisation results in lower performance, not more. Why does it matter how many instructions per cycle it can do? What matters is the total performance. Instructions per cycle is a very old fashioned way of looking at CPU speed, more so than ever now with multicore setups and microcode interpretors. yet again you show a complete lack of understanding about how a modern SoC works. Anyone could design a CPU like the A10, only apple does, because only Apple need one like that, it doesnt show genius, or more advanced design, its just different to similarly performing ARM and Intel CPUs. PhaseBurn Google's been in the hardware field for a very, very long time, originally using Scorpion ARM-based CPUs that predate the SnapDragon, even (https://www.wired.com/2012/09/pluto-switch/). Despite what Variety says about Gulati joining to design SoCs for the Pixel line, I'm guessing that their internal SoC group will end up working on a lot of their platform networking and datacenter fabric next generation designs, in addition to anything they do on a future Pixel phone. Shelly-Man Vol 2 I'm pretty excited to hear about this news. I've always wanna see Google have their own custom chips for their hardware. Google love plot twist #2 roberto.elena I'm personally more interested in a Google SoC for Chromebooks. It's not that I don't find this news interesting for mobiles, but the biggest benefit, even more important than improved performance, is extended OS support. At the current pace of hardware improvement, I'm not interested in owning a phone for more than 1 or 2 years, but a Chromebook is a different story. I would keep it for several years. destinyhud good point. intel is fast but have issues with android apps. other oem are not that fast enough and qualcomm wont come to chromebook at least for now. so this chip used in chromebook pixel would be awesome Midnitte Sort of wish somebody (Intel, AMD,.... Google) would purchase MediaTek and position them to actually compete with Snapdragon, so that we could all benefit from longer/quicker upgrades, not to mention performance. someone755 MediaTek's strategy is much like AMD's was just a few years ago in the desktop space. The money for them is up to where OEMs (who make low-end and midrange phones) are willing to pay for the chips -- any higher and they don't have the knowledge/technology/budget to produce something more powerful. Any lower and, well, this is as low as it can go, and the other competitors (Qualcomm, Intel) have worse-performing chips available for the price that MediaTek offers theirs at. Why that is, I have no clue, but I suspect it could have something to do with Qcom having a monopoly on ARM-based chips, and Intel thinking that their overpriced-desktop-chips-with-no-competitor strategy is going to work here, in a highly competitive environment. The point here being that MediaTek works off tight margins and sells in large quantities. Restructuring this process so that it fits our idea of a Qualcomm competitor would be expensive, and definitely riskier than what the payoff is worth to the investor. reggjoo Maybe he can help bring that single core performance up to apple levels. It won't really make a big difference in the global grand scheme of things, but it would kill all that bragging rights talk. usamaisawake I know we can never know, but I honestly think that the A-chips are, on their own, just really damn good chips. iOS optimization helps, but I think a lot of it is Apple's designers. Marty I'm liking the sound of that. But going by Google's declaration that the Pixel phones are made by Google when in fact they are designed and made by HTC, these SoCs will probably be shelf-bought from the cheapest vendor. destinyhud i am sorry u r wrong at this part. designed by google and made by HTC. same like apples designed by apple claim. It clearly shows HTC footprints in both hardware and software design. destinyhud AA article says nothing about hardware footprint just software foot print. software is not hardware. also there are similar article which said google was building nexus by HTC and finally decided to make their own phone which is why u could find htc code when it was in early development. we are not talking about software here again. Marty The HTC hardware footprint is clearly seen in the design. And it's noteworthy that the software would have any OEM influence at all since Android is a Google creation. You can claim whatever you want, but the evidence is clear and has been clear since the Pixels were released. Economy Federal Reserve Capitol Report Economic Report Columns Darrell Delamaide Rex Nutting Tools Economic Calendar Real Estate realtor.com My MarketWatch Watchlist Alerts Games Log In Home Industries Automobiles We still don’t know what Apple is up to with driverless cars By Claudia Assis Published: June 13, 2017 2:30 p.m. ET Share CEO Tim Cook finally admits Apple is working on something, but doesn’t really say what that something is MarketWatch photo illustration/Bloomberg By ClaudiaAssis Reporter Apple Inc. Chief Executive Tim Cook has confirmed the company is working on driverless-car technology, but Silicon Valley’s worst-kept secret is nowhere near being entirely revealed. In an interview aired for the first time Tuesday, Cook told Bloomberg TV that Apple AAPL, -0.60%  is focusing on “autonomous systems.” One purpose of such systems is driverless cars, and there are others, he said. “We sort of see it as the mother of all AI projects,” one of the most difficult to AI issues to work on, he said. Cook went on to say that autonomy is a core technology Apple views as “very important,” but the company is “not really saying,” from a product point of view, that is what it will do. Apple’s route to a driverless-car world, therefore, remains a question the company is none too keen on answering, after years of dodging questions about whether it is aiming for an “Apple car.” It could take a page from Alphabet Inc.’s GOOGL, -0.80% GOOG, -0.89%  Waymo, which focuses on the total hardware and software package for self-driving cars “while leaving vehicle production to established auto makers,” said Karl Brauer, an analyst with Kelly Blue Book. That would put Google’s parent company and Apple in direct competition, similar to their rivalry in the smartphone world, where two systems, Alphabet’s Android and Apple’s iOS, dominate, he said. Apple did not immediately return a request for comment. Read more: Alphabet self-driving cars could be worth $70 billion, challenge Tesla If it chooses to work on software only, Apple would be in direct competition with traditional auto makers like Tesla Inc. TSLA, -1.40%  , which have raced to get autonomous cars on the road in as little as three years. Tesla has developed its own software and related advanced-driver assistance systems, the muscle to the brains provided, since October, by an onboard Nvidia Corp. NVDA, +0.43%  AI “supercomputer.” The AI computer makes sense of the data gathered by the car’s several sensors, and Nvidia has said it can handle full self-driving capabilities, using AI and machine learning to discern a pedestrian from a utility pole on the path of a driverless car. Apple in April received permission from California regulators to test its driverless cars on the state’s public roads, using three modified Lexus SUVs. Several other companies, from startups to parts manufacturers, other tech companies and traditional auto makers, also are testing their vehicles in California. In a late April letter to state regulators asking for changes in California’s proposed driverless-car policies, Apple said it was “investing heavily in the study of machine learning and automation,” and that it was “excited” about the future of automation in many areas, including transportation. Apple stock has suffered of late, falling 6.5% in the past month, but is still up 26% so far in 2017. That easily eclipses the 7.9% increase this year for the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.07%  , which counts Apple as a member, and the 8.5% gain for the S&P 500 index. SPX, -0.22%   More from MarketWatch Stay away from bitcoin — it’s complete garbage Oil prices fall to 7-month low; natural gas rallies Is now the time to buy battered energy stocks? Quote References AAPL -0.87 -0.60% GOOGL -7.75 -0.80% GOOG -8.45 -0.89% TSLA -5.32 -1.40% NVDA +0.65 +0.43% DJIA -14.66 -0.07% SPX -5.46 -0.22% Show all references Most Popular Stay away from bitcoin — it’s complete garbage The smart money is refusing to buy big tech stocks now Bitcoin is suddenly on pace to have its worst week since 2015 Trump won’t be removed from office — and that’s why the Trump Trade is over How Asia Tech Titans Are Gaining Ground on U.S. Rivals Claudia Assis Claudia Assis is a San Francisco-based reporter for MarketWatch. Top News U.S. News World News Voices Entertainment Movies Music TV Odd News Defense Energy Sports Fantasy Football NFL NBA MLB NHL Golf Tennis College Football College Basketball Science Health Photos Latest Photos 2016 Olympics News Entertainment Sports Features Archives Archive The Almanac Search Home / Top News / U.S. News Apple issues $1B bond to finance 'green' energy projects By Allen Cone   |   June 13, 2017 at 3:29 PM Follow @upi Comments June 13 (UPI) -- Apple issued its second "green" bond -- valued at $1 billion -- Tuesday to fund the tech company's renewable energy efforts. Last year the company, based in Cupertino, Calf., sold $1.5 billion worth of bonds in its quest to run 100 percent of its operations on renewable energy. The latest bond, which matures in 2027, will yield 95 to 100 basis points more than U.S. Treasuries, according to a Bloomberg source. And they are expected to be rated Aa1. Bank of America, Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase set up the sale. Apple said the bond sale will also help support its plan for a closed-loop supply chain -- products made entirely using recycled materials. The company is investing in several non-fossil fuel projects: solar energy, hydroelectric plants and biogas facilities in Oregon, North Carolina, Nevada, Arizona and California. That includes $850 million on a 130-megawatt solar farm near San Francisco over the next quarter century. Apple says its new Cupertino headquarters, Apple Park, runs entirely on renewable energy and includes rooftop solar panels supplemented by fuel cells. The 2.8 million-square-foot main building, which is ring-shaped in curved glass. Apple also has received permission to sell power to the wholesale energy markets. Two weeks ago, Apple criticized President Donald Trump's decision to pull the the United States out of the Paris climate accord to curb greenhouse-gas emissions signed by almost 200 countries. "Leadership from the business community is essential to address the threat of climate change," Lisa Jackson, Apple's vice president of environment, policy and social initiatives, said in the statement. The company was among several companies pledging to continue supporting efforts to meet the Paris agreement. Apple has cash and equivalents totaling $257 billion. But Apple has issued $99 billion to fund stock buybacks and dividends, because most resources are held outside the United States and would be subject to a 35 percent corporate income tax if it moved to the United States. Click to Skip Ad Closing in... Tech Entertainment Business Deals Science Politics About Opinions Image Source: Apple There’s no reason to get excited about Apple’s interest in self-driving cars Yoni Heisler @edibleapple June 13th, 2017 at 2:52 PM Share Tweet In something of an unusual move, Apple CEO Tim Cook sat down with Bloomberg today and revealed that Apple is actively developing self-driving car technologies. In response to a question about Apple’s car ambitions, Cook stopped playing coy and flatly stated: “We’re focusing on autonomous systems. It’s a core technology that we view as very important. We sort of see it as the mother of all AI projects.” Cook’s revelation here is incredibly surprising because it’s completely out of character for Apple executives to divulge even a crumb of information about R&D initiatives. Indeed, one of Apple’s defining traits is its stubborn reluctance to confirm or deny any type of new technology they happen to be working on. Don't Miss: Behold the Google Pixel 2 of your dreams So what exactly is going on here? Why is Tim Cook seemingly taking Apple’s tried and true playbook and throwing it out the window? Is it possible Cook wants to generate some excitement in the wake of Apple shares taking a dramatic tumble this week? Or, perhaps, is this Cook’s way of assuring skeptical analysts that Apple won’t miss the next big thing? Cook’s motivations notwithstanding, you might want to temper any expectations of Apple turning the automotive industry on its head. While Apple has a history of entering new product categories and making a splash, it’s only been able to do that when entering a product category filled to the brim with unimaginative and lazy incumbents. The auto industry today, however, is a far cry from the MP3 player and smartphone markets Apple was able to upend with ease many years ago. The reality is that the auto industry has a number of sophisticated players with long track records of incredible innovation, from BMW and Porsche to Tesla. What’s more, it’s not exactly clear where Apple is going to profit from self-driving technology in the first place. Is Apple going to sell its software solution to third-party automakers? That seems like a non-starter given that most of the luxury car makers are intent on going it alone. And as for Apple releasing its own branded car, well, that’s even more unlikely for a variety of reasons, not the least of which is that it would require an absolutely mammoth outlay of cash for small profits relative to Apple’s size. All that aside, there’s no evidence at the moment to suggest that Apple’s mythical self-driving car technology will be so great as to render competing systems second-rate. Far from it, the language Cook used when describing Apple’s work in the area is eerily reminiscent of what Cook previously said about the Apple TV. “We’ll see where it takes us,” Cook said of the company’s efforts. “We’re not really saying from a product point of view what we will do.” Until Apple has something compelling to show off, there’s no reason to get excited about the fact that Apple is throwing R&D resources at a problem that other companies take much more seriously than Apple, namely Tesla. Google hires ex-Apple chipset veteran to help design SoCs for Pixel phones Ryne Hager Follow View All Posts 2017/06/13 11:36am PDTJun 13, 2017 46 Plus 1 on G+ 195 Share on Facebook 52 Share on Twitter Total Shares293 Google News Google's hardware plans for the future are getting bigger. Variety is reporting that Google has hired Manu Gulati, a hardware architect, away from Apple. Gulati is reported as having previously played a significant role in the development of Apple's SoCs for the last eight years and was hired sometime in the last few weeks. His new title at Google is Lead SOC Architect, and he's expected to work on custom chipsets for future Pixel phones. If Manu Gulati can apply the same black magic to Google's future products as he did on Apple's custom chips, things could be fantastic. Apple's "A" series chips are amazing pieces of hardware. Though Apple does license ARM's tech, unlike other manufacturers, they don't just toss the licensed reference designs on a wafer. Apple has bent over backward to optimize their silicon architecture for iOS, and the resulting performance on Apple devices definitely demonstrates that. Although some Android chipset vendors, such as Qualcomm, do make custom designs like the Kryo, for whatever reason Apple's custom hardware (combined with their software) has held an edge in performance for years. For most of us, any advantage the A series chips have doesn't make any difference without the Android operating system. But if Google is able to bring the same degree of performance enhancements and customization over into their future hardware, the future of Android SoC performance could be bright. After the dark and regressive ages of the Snapdragon 808/810 and Qualcomm's rushed 64bit development cycle, I would like nothing more than to see Google bring a first party chipset in a future Pixel device. And who knows, they might even sell it to other manufacturers, increasing competition in the currently stagnant mobile chipset space. Gulati joining Google finally lends credence to the old stories of Google's interest in SoC designing. And it appears to be full steam ahead, as supplemental job postings for SoC design have appeared on Google Careers. Whether these efforts result in a new custom chipset by Google, or we just see some new specialized hardware for machine learning, either way, things should be interesting. Source: Linkedin Via: Variety Tags apple ARM chipset hardware SoC subscribe ... Previous Story [Lame] Netflix places limits on how many times you can download certain content ... Duder12 HUGE kabiluddin Guess we'll see the new custom soc in late 2018/9 Honestly can't wait. destinyhud pixel 3 then!!! Godspoken I recall "Google silicon" being referenced last year as a future goal of the Pixel, very exciting. blackice85 Isn't that one of the things holding them back from providing updates for longer periods of time too? Could be a big deal not just for the performance gains. Gregory That Project Treble thing or how do you call it in O is also all about cutting on dependencies from third parties like Qualcomm. blackice85 Oh I hadn't heard about that, I bet this is one aspect of it then. Duder12 Project Treble doesnt improve years of update support. It brings updates faster since Qualcomm and OEMs can work on software updates at the same time. Qualcomm can still decide to not ship new drivers for old versions of Android just like they always have. Google doing their own SOC is the only real answer Gregory From my understanding, it eliminates the need for the drivers to be updated in the first place. someone755 You can't expect to not update drivers with new Android versions. Say there's an Android system API that a driver adheres to. As something banal, let's say we have a driver that controls whether the hardware button backlight is on or off, and that the system can control whether it is either on or off. Then a newer Android version appears which supports both the old API but also a newer one, wherein the hardware backlight can be controlled as if it were analog (from 0-255 for example). Then, the third system version comes out that ditches support for the old API and only still supports the newer one. Yes the OEM could hack things up so that values 0-254 would mean the light is off and then 255 would mean it's on, but this further complicates both the user experience and app compatibility as well as future system version compatibility. At this point if you want a stable and future-proof software solution, you absolutely have to update the driver to support the new API. And if the backlight vendor can't provide one, then it's more trouble than it's worth for the OEM to do the hack themselves and they just post a note online saying your device won't get upgraded, leaving you with no choice but to either resort to community hacks or buy a new device. Yes the example is completely idiotic but it serves as an example of why you can't go around updating devices without driver updates. Aside from the functionality aspect there are many security flaws that could affect a driver. And not updating that huge gaping hole in your security while providing monthly 'security patches' that claim to solve security threats is just inane. At that point why even bother with security patches if you can't expect chipset vendors to fix the problems in their closed-source firmware, or hold them accountable for it. Gregory While I completely understand your point, I'd like to extend it to say that there could be such a backlight that can be either on or off, and it's a hardware limitation, so it isn't possible to fully implement the new API on that device. I mean, hardware configurations vary, it's a matter of fact. The point of HAL (hardware abstraction layer) is to abstract away the differences across the underlying hardware, and provide a unified API for the system services to interact with said hardware. If the HAL doesn't provide support for some new feature that was added in a system update but the hardware could technically support it, it still means that the system would behave as though that feature isn't supported by the hardware, and that's it. I'd rather have a device that doesn't support that new feature than a device that is no longer updated. And security... How about people ALWAYS check for buffer boundaries before copying memory? What do they do with all that time and disk space they save? Or, at least, if they're that lazy, run a static analyzer on your code and fix whatever it finds. And run it in valgrind to find memory leaks. It's not that hard to write vulnerability-free code from the start. someone755 But a device will never pass certification, either by Google or an FCC-like entity or another office, with broken features. This is exactly why the 8974 line got dropped -- the hardware didn't support a feature that Google wanted so they didn't let any 8974 device pass CTS. How do you think people running Nougat just fine on their hammerheads (via one custom ROM or another) feel about this conundrum when they've been cut short an entire system update because of Google's insane chip requirements? It's easy to know how to prevent bad code but often times projects start simple and private and unoptimized, and then grow into something much larger that's hard to maintain. A classic example is Android itself (look at all the memory leaks that L introduced). Gregory Well... If a device passed certification by Google (CTS) and carriers, that feature was optional from the beginning, right? Android does already support a plethora of different hardware configurations with different capabilities. If a device didn't have some feature at launch, I don't expect it to have that feature enabled with a software update. CTS is about keeping compatibility with apps (it tests public APIs), it has nothing to do with drivers and hardware. There are literally no hardware requirements that make it impossible to update existing devices more than a year or two. Carrier certification is about device interfacing correctly with carrier equipment, it did so well when it was released and certified, so just don't touch the modem firmware because it's already doing its job good enough, as simple as that. There are exactly zero reasons to modify the HAL for system updates provided HAL and the rest of the system are properly separated, which, from my understanding, they are with Project Treble. It also adds CTS-like standardized test suite for these things. What the hell is 8974? someone755 Msm8974. The Snapdragon 800 platform that phones like the N5, Z3, G2, S5, M8 etc were based on. That got blocked from receiving any sort of updates because Google decided that Vulkan or GL 3.1 was necessary for the upgrade. Not that modern low-end phones are capable of performing the task that the requirement was set for anyways. Basically the thing my entire argument is set around but alright... Owais Lone > Qualcomm can still decide to not ship new drivers for old versions of Android just like they always have. ... and Project Treble will enable device vendors to still ship updates in this exact case. Project Treble cuts out qualcom and SoC manufacturers out of the update cycle. The device vendors will be bottleneck and decision makers now. someone755 This is incorrect. Please see my reply to Gregory above. Owais Lone Your example exactly illustrates the problem now. Project Treble is supposed to abstract these internal hardware level ABIs/APIs so vendors don't have to re-implement the whole layer again. Only time when SOC vendors will have to update their code is when Project Treble itself comes out with a breaking change and a major version upgrade. Of course, vendors might have to or want to make changes here and there but the abstraction should save them from re-doing all of it on every update and if the vendor does not want to improve/optimize with every update, they shouldn't have to make any changes at all unless Treble itself comes out with an incompatible update. someone755 And say that Android P is the one where the button backlight brightness from my example becomes an analog value and the digital on/off API is dropped. Then the phones that incorporate this function will either have to have the driver updated or will not get updated to the next Android version. This is a problem and always will be, as long as chip vendors are not held responsible and held to a higher standard, and as long as the entities that certify devices for daily use (CTS, FCC etc) have some standards themselves (in the sense of not letting devices with broken/missing core features pass). Owais Lone If such a change happens at the HW level, it'll be abstracted at the treble API level so phones that leverage treble API will not need any change at all. Vendors would need to update their code if the change happened in Treble's apI itself which is extremely unlikely as it'll defeat the purpose of having Treble in the first place. That said, there will be major updates to Treble which might break backward compatibility but it's Google's job to keep those changes at a minimal or the whole idea will be worthless. someone755 This is exactly what I'm saying -- if Treble changes (which it most probably will across Android versions, as the system has changed until now), the chip vendors will *have* to provide updates. And there is no way around this limitation, Treble or not, if Google makes some absurd changes then phones won't get updated. Owais Lone Yes, that is true but why would that happen in the first place? That would completely defeat the purpose. Treble will most likely always be backward compatible. It'll probably only add new features and new APIs but not break existing ones. That's how I would handle the project. MJ I am not as excited (yet) as most of you are about this. I see two possible scenarios coming out of custom chipset from Google... 1.) The main reason Apple's SoC performs better is because it's optimized for iOS and only iOS. It is not properly documented so no other OS can really run it. I would rather stick with a Qualcomm SoC if Google goes down this road. 2.) Google creates a fully open and documented SoC but it performs no better than Apple's or Qualcomm's chips. I would prefer a fully open and documented chipset that can compete as good or better than anything else out there. Possible? I don't know... Regardless, I suspect Google is looking to make some custom hardware for AI or VR first before we see a custom chipset for a phone.
