Now, apple A10x is very competitive especially considering that A10x is fan-less design. Enough said. Just_No_Stop Firstly you dont say which Intel chip, the fastest laptop chip is WAY faster than the A10x. Secondly, they run 2 totally different OSes, one is very much single threaded, that can run limited threads when it does run multi-thread, and as such can dedicate the entire CPU to the benchmark. OSX is very multi-threaded, and doesnt do that, it will always run more background threads. Thirdly the A10x isnt a phone chip, its a laptop/tablet chip, and actually eats battery like crazy when full throttle, and gets very hot when it does, and as so doesnt do so for long. Thinker Geekbench 4 is functionally same across all platforms. Thus comparable. Read Geekbench blog. Oh forgot one more thing...A10x has 3 CPU cores while Intel chip above has 4 CPU cores. That only further makes multi-thread score more impressive!! Intel chip above is standard intel in base Macbook PRO in 2016. If you take fan out of Intel devices, then would that equalize things for you?? Lol. Wanna bet which will be better?! Just_No_Stop It might be functionally the same, but the OS is not, and despite claims (by the developer which has a bias to sell its product) its not comparable across platforms. It doesnt even generate the same score on the same CPU between OSX, Linux and Windows, let alone iOS and android. The base Macbook Pro from 2016 has 2 cores, so again.. which chip is it? The A10x cannot run full throttle for long, the Intel can run flat out all the time, doing the same task, if even remotely prolonged, the Intel will win. The Intel is all much more flexible than the A10x. It capable of unoptimised maths that the A10x would simple die a death trying to run. Its is at least an order of magnitude faster than the A10x, which a full desktop class OS needs. Thats why there is no A10x powered Macbook Pro. Thinker Intel has a fan. Take out fan and what happens? Just_No_Stop It would probably not be able to run as long, but it would more than manage the few seconds per test of Geekbench. Thinker Huh?! Wtf?! Please stop talking. Just_No_Stop How is that not true? I have run geekbench multiple times on my laptop and desktop, and the fan doesnt kick in on my laptop and doesnt throttle up on my desktop. Its a very brief, and very poor benchmark. You still fail to understand how the usage scenarios in an iPad Pro and a desktop class PC are completely different, which is why one goes for single core performance, and the other multicore. So i will repeat, its not that Intel cant beat Apple, its that they dont need to. Its made even worse by the fact that most laptops are seriously storage speed limited, even an SSD only helps so much, and the CPU is still waiting. The A10, in a laptop would be awful. One core would be almost always in use for background tasks, and as such would burn through battery. Android is not that dissimilar, it has far more background activity than iOS, and therefore needs less powerful, more numerous cores that use less power. The trick is making all those cores useful when you need to run a single powerful task. This is something that Android has got much better at, but it doesnt really show up well in benchmarks. Thinker The Apple iPad PRO 12.9 from 2015 with merely 2 CPU cores active at any single time (Apple A9X) and 4 GB of RAM. Yet with iOS11, it can run FOUR active windows at once. Yes, 4 windows all active and you can interact with all 4. Now, on the other hand, on Android with those 8-12 cores of CPU, you see apps constantly being kicked out of memory despite 6-8 GB RAM! Background activity you say? BS! BTW, a single powerful task does NOT need 6-8 cores of CPU. Again, please STFU! You’re really embarrassing yourself! Hrishikesh Bisen You are a plan idiot. Thinker Cross-Platform Designed from the ground-up for cross-platform comparisons, Geekbench 4 allows you to compare system performance across devices, processor architectures, and operating systems. Geekbench 4 supports Android, iOS, macOS, Windows, and Linux. Source: Geekbench. Just_No_Stop Source.. the company that makes and wants to sell the benchmark. Unfortunately reality doesnt support that claim. Thinker Lol. Geekbench is universally accepted. Just_No_Stop by plenty of sites that have no idea how it works, which is most of them. Thinker Here's a comparison of interest: http://browser.geekbench.com/v4/cpu/compare/3042292?baseline=3036382 Just_No_Stop iOS is not comparable to Windows 10. The Intel chip is 18% faster than the A10X in multi-core. geekbench does very badly with hyperthreading, which for applications that make use of it adds a huge performance advantage. Many apps now use it. It should also be noted that the A10x is a SoC, that includes hardware acceleration for some things that the Intel chip isnt designed for, and has little use traditionally on Laptops, this further distorts the score in the A10x favour. Dont get me wrong, its a good CPU, but its not all that. If there was an ARM Windows 10 it wouldnt run as well on the A10x as x64 windows does on Core iX. It should also be noted that there are 3 SoC that beat the standard A10 on Android, which also is more background threaded than iOS, and as such cant dedicate 100% of the CPU to the benchmark. Thinker Remind me...doesn't intel have that TURBO thingy? 3 Android SoC that beat A10?!?! 😂 Dude, you make me laugh!! Hint: single core is far more important. And remember A10 is dual core at any one time unlike Android SoC. Some of those Android are actually firing up all EIGHT cores to beat Apple's two!!! Just_No_Stop Single core is more important on iOS, not Android. Do you really think ARM and Qualcomm and Samsung, who have been at this for years, cant make a CPU as fast as Apple? They can, but the platform doesnt require such Single core performance, and making a CPU like that would hurt performance of Android, not help it. ARM has done extensive testing of such setups, but has rejected them for a reason. If you must know the A10 is very similar in structure to the Intel Core, which is why its fast, but its also why it cant run 4 cores and be power efficient. Its clear you have no idea how a CPU works, or an OS, and you put WAY to much faith in a commercial benchmark. Thinker Let's test your knowledge since you claim to know so much...how many instruction set per cycle can A10 do vs S835? No, Samsung and Qualcomm do NOT use custom design cores dumbass. They use generic core design from ARM. In fact I believe S835 CPU core design took a step backward too. But you know all this already. APPLE uses fully custom cores designed upon ARMv8 architecture. What you wrote is pure ignorance. Please stop. Just_No_Stop Qualcomm do use custom designs, Samsung doesnt, and yet the Exynos 8895 is faster than the A10.. It seems you are the ignorant one. Thinker Wrong. Anandtech: "The new Kryo 280, despite the similar name, shares no design DNA with the original Kryo. Its an octa-core, big.LITTLE configuration with four “performance” cores and four lower-power “efficiency” cores. What makes Kryo 280 unique, however, is that it’s the first design to use ARM’s new "Built on ARM Cortex Technology" (BoC) license, which allows vendors to customize ARM cores. This new semi-custom option gives vendors the ability to differentiate their products from those using ARM’s stock cores while avoiding the more costly route of creating a fully-custom design from scratch." Again, like I said above, S835 CPU core was a step BACKWARDS. It is basically a generic CPU core with memory controller from Qualcomm. S820 used custom cores but with S835, Qualcomm used generic. Again, you never answered my other question. How many instruction set per cycle can A10 do vs S835? STFU dude. You are ignorant. Just_No_Stop You realise that a SoC isnt just the cores right? The memory controller and GPU are what make the 835 custom. If the 835 and the Exynos are generic then why is the Exynos faster despite a lower clock? Again, you lack understanding, all you can do is regurgitate rubbish you have read on a website. Exynos is almost entirely ARM reference, the 835 is not, generic cores maybe, but otherwise completely custom. Sadly all that customisation results in lower performance, not more. Why does it matter how many instructions per cycle it can do? What matters is the total performance. Instructions per cycle is a very old fashioned way of looking at CPU speed, more so than ever now with multicore setups and microcode interpretors. yet again you show a complete lack of understanding about how a modern SoC works. Anyone could design a CPU like the A10, only apple does, because only Apple need one like that, it doesnt show genius, or more advanced design, its just different to similarly performing ARM and Intel CPUs. Frankly I'm just blocking you now, since you arent interested in learning. Thinker Damn you're ignorant. I see that you're backtracking like crazy!! Lol No, S835 CPU core is generic. No one talked about GPU. LOL INSTRUCTIONS PER CYCLE has nothing to do about CPU speed!! Wtf are you talking about?! Typical Android dumbass who thinks he knows tech. Anyone can design like Apple yet everyone is envious of Apple chip design team, including Google!! You're a dumbass. Thinker Even today, i am still laughing at your ignorance!!! Thanks for the laugh!! PhaseBurn Google's been in the hardware field for a very, very long time, originally using Scorpion ARM-based CPUs that predate the SnapDragon, even (https://www.wired.com/2012/09/pluto-switch/). Despite what Variety says about Gulati joining to design SoCs for the Pixel line, I'm guessing that their internal SoC group will end up working on a lot of their platform networking and datacenter fabric next generation designs, in addition to anything they do on a future Pixel phone. Shelly-Man Vol 2 I'm pretty excited to hear about this news. I've always wanna see Google have their own custom chips for their hardware. Google love plot twist #2 roberto.elena I'm personally more interested in a Google SoC for Chromebooks. It's not that I don't find this news interesting for mobiles, but the biggest benefit, even more important than improved performance, is extended OS support. At the current pace of hardware improvement, I'm not interested in owning a phone for more than 1 or 2 years, but a Chromebook is a different story. I would keep it for several years. destinyhud good point. intel is fast but have issues with android apps. other oem are not that fast enough and qualcomm wont come to chromebook at least for now. so this chip used in chromebook pixel would be awesome Midnitte Sort of wish somebody (Intel, AMD,.... Google) would purchase MediaTek and position them to actually compete with Snapdragon, so that we could all benefit from longer/quicker upgrades, not to mention performance. someone755 MediaTek's strategy is much like AMD's was just a few years ago in the desktop space. The money for them is up to where OEMs (who make low-end and midrange phones) are willing to pay for the chips -- any higher and they don't have the knowledge/technology/budget to produce something more powerful. Any lower and, well, this is as low as it can go, and the other competitors (Qualcomm, Intel) have worse-performing chips available for the price that MediaTek offers theirs at. Why that is, I have no clue, but I suspect it could have something to do with Qcom having a monopoly on ARM-based chips, and Intel thinking that their overpriced-desktop-chips-with-no-competitor strategy is going to work here, in a highly competitive environment. The point here being that MediaTek works off tight margins and sells in large quantities. Restructuring this process so that it fits our idea of a Qualcomm competitor would be expensive, and definitely riskier than what the payoff is worth to the investor. reggjoo Maybe he can help bring that single core performance up to apple levels. It won't really make a big difference in the global grand scheme of things, but it would kill all that bragging rights talk. usamaisawake I know we can never know, but I honestly think that the A-chips are, on their own, just really damn good chips. iOS optimization helps, but I think a lot of it is Apple's designers. Marty I'm liking the sound of that. But going by Google's declaration that the Pixel phones are made by Google when in fact they are designed and made by HTC, these SoCs will probably be shelf-bought from the cheapest vendor. destinyhud i am sorry u r wrong at this part. designed by google and made by HTC. same like apples designed by apple claim. Marty Wrong. It's now known the Pixels were designed and made by HTC. http://www.androidauthority.com/google-hidden-htc-involvement-google-pixel-xl-code-723953/ https://www.forbes.com/sites/jeanbaptiste/2016/10/05/the-pixel-smartphone-is-actually-made-by-htc-not-google/#52ca3eb1e99a https://www.androidcentral.com/google-pixel-htc-will-real-manufacturer-googles-phones-share-glory destinyhud its now knows to just u or what?? because eveyone know its designed by google. but they def have HTC previous device influence. google interview clearly said they tried to design pixel as non iphone design as possible. we are talking about hardware. finding code reference is not equal to HTC made hardware. how does that login even correlate? all the article u posted said it is made by HTC and i didnt disagree on that. it is made by HTC but designed by Google. try harder. https://www.cnet.com/special-reports/google-pixel-how-google-designed-its-first-real-phone/ Marty Read the AA article. It clearly shows HTC footprints in both hardware and software design. destinyhud AA article says nothing about hardware footprint just software foot print. software is not hardware. also there are similar article which said google was building nexus by HTC and finally decided to make their own phone which is why u could find htc code when it was in early development. we are not talking about software here again. Xiaomi Mi Pad 3 review: For those who dream of owning an iPad mini that runs Android Jeff Beck Follow View All Posts 2017/06/12 12:00pm PDTJun 12, 2017 3 Plus 1 on G+ 51 Share on Facebook 33 Share on Twitter Total Shares87 Mi Pad 3 News Reviews Tablet Reviews Xiaomi / MIUI Article Contents 1 Specs 2 The Good 3 The Not So Good 4 Design 5 Display 6 Cameras 7 Performance and battery 8 Software 9 Conclusion Have you ever walked through a mall and passed by the Apple store and stared longingly at the iPad Mini and thought to yourself, "Man, I sure wish I could buy one of those that ran Android"? Well, I have some (kinda) good news for you. Today I'm reviewing the Xiaomi Mi Pad 3, a 7.9in Chinese tablet that has no shame in borrowing a healthy dose of design cues from a certain fruit logo-bearing competitor. For better or worse, the Mi Pad 3 looks an awful lot like an iPad Mini in Android clothing. Is it as good, or better than the tablet it is imitating? Let's find out. Specs SoC Mediatek MT8176 RAM 4GB Storage 64GB Display 7.9-inch 1536 x 2048 IPS LCD Battery 6,600 mAh Camera 13MP, 5MP Software Android 7.0, MIUI8 Measurements 200.4 x 132.6 x 7 mm, 328g The Good Design and build If you like the design and build quality of the iPad mini, you will like the way this looks and feels. Performance Yes, it's a Mediatek processor, but during my month of testing it's been quite a solid performer. Display The display is rumored to be the same one used in the iPad mini; it's crisp, vibrant, and responsive. Battery Longevity is good, with 8-10 hours of screen on time. The Not So Good Speakers They sound ok, but their placement is lousy. Capacitive buttons Come on, even Samsung gave those up. Software Running Android 7.0, but key features are missing. No fingerprint reader This is something that's become a standard feature in the last year, it sucks to go back to PIN unlocking. Camera Come on, no one expects a tablet camera to be any good, and Xiaomi doesn't disappoint - this one is lousy. Design It's impossible to look at the Mi Pad 3 and not be reminded of an iPad mini. The looks are strikingly similar, intentionally so. The size, weight, thickness, bezels, and camera placement are all almost identical. The back is a flat slab of aluminum with rounded sides, similar to - you guessed it - the iPad mini. Really, the only things that set it apart from the iPad are the placement of the speakers and buttons, and the lack of a home button on the front. Yeah, it's pretty much a blatant copy, but at least the source material is well designed. Hate on Apple all you want, the iPad mini is a nice looking device that's easy to hold, and so is the Mi Pad 3 by extension. Let's take a little tour of the tablet. At the top left corner of the device is a headphone jack, and centered at the bottom of the tablet is a USB-C port. The left side is bare and the right side features a power bottom and volume rocker about an inch below the top. The buttons are the only parts that feel a bit cheap on this tablet. While they are made of aluminum and have nice feedback, they are a bit too loose in their sockets, which makes them wiggle when touched and rattle when shaken. A small thing, but hard to ignore once you notice it. The front of the device is dominated by the display, surrounded by black bezels of moderate size top and bottom. The navigation buttons are back-lit capacitive keys at the bottom of the display arranged in the Samsung fashion, which feels backwards to many users, including myself. That's two things I really don't care for in one aspect of the tablet. Now, the buttons can be remapped in the settings to change the back button to the left and menu to the right. However, the icons can't be changed as they are back-lit cutouts, so instead of fixing the layout, it makes it even worse as the icons no longer match their actions. On the plus side, the duration that the buttons stay lit can be adjusted, or the back-light can be disabled completely system wide, or while using specific apps. You might have noticed that the home button is not a fingerprint scanner as it is on the iPad mini. There isn't one anywhere else on the device either, nor is there NFC, or a microSD card slot. Now, 64GB of internal space helps offset the need for expandable storage, and you're not likely to use a tablet to pay for your groceries with Android Pay, but the missing fingerprint scanner is frustrating. That's become a pretty standard feature on devices in 2017, and I miss it here. Going back to using a pin number to unlock my device feels archaic. Funny how quickly times change. Flipping the device over, there's not a lot going on. A 13MP camera occupies the upper left corner, and twin speakers sit at the bottom of the rear panel spaced an inch and a half apart. The speakers are stereo, which is laughable as an inch and a half of separation is barely sufficient for your ears to distinguish the difference between the channels. They are also completely useless as stereo speakers when holding the tablet in landscape mode, the way I assume 99 percent of people orient their tablet when watching a movie. They still play audio in stereo when the tablet is oriented in landscape, meaning you have a top and bottom channel instead of a right and left channel. That's just bizarre. In terms of volume, the speakers are about as loud as you'd expect with a tablet this size. In a quiet room they are perfectly fine for watching a show or playing a game. They don't have any low end, but they are clear and distortion free. Audio from the headphone jack is great, with enough power to drive a set of 50mm headphones well above a comfortable listening level. Taken as a whole, the tablet is very well constructed and feels light yet solid in hand. There are no gaps, the glass panel on the front is completely uniform, and weight is evenly distributed across the device. If you want to get a good approximation for how it feels to hold one, get your hands on an iPad mini. A tech novice might not even be able to tell them apart with a blindfold on. Display The highlight of the Mi Pad 3 is definitely the IPS LCD display. Its resolution of 2048×1536 is identical to that of the screen found in the iPad mini. It's rumored that the display is, in fact, sourced from the same supplier as the one that adorns Apple's smallest tablet. That wouldn't surprise me at all, as it is quite brilliant. Colors are deep and rich, black levels are respectable, and the white balance is well calibrated. It has all the nits you need for outdoor viewing, and even more importantly, in my opinion, it can drop to delightfully low brightness levels for late night use. The LCD panel can dim even further than the AMOLED screen on my Nexus 6P, something I find impressive. A number of tweaks can be made to the screen through the settings panel. The tint can be adjusted and a black and white mode can also be enabled to supposedly increase battery life. I don't believe color has the same impact on power consumption on an LCD panel as it does on an AMOLED display, but the setting is there nonetheless and will make Gothic and noir fans happy. There's also a reading mode that amps up the red levels for nighttime viewing, a feature I always love to see implemented on the system level. Cameras Frankly, I sometimes wonder why we even bother with this section in tablet reviews. There seems to be an unwritten law that tablet cameras must be lousy, and man, Xiaomi is a law-abiding company in that regard. I've take a few shots for you to look at, because, hey, I already spent some time typing a header for this section, so why not. Previous Next At first blush the pictures look acceptable, but once you take a closer look it's apparent that the images are bland, soft, and lacking vibrancy. All these were taken with the 13MP rear camera, the photos from the front facing camera were even worse. The selfies I took made me look absolutely awful, so I vainly excluded them from the review. The image quality is mediocre, even for a tablet, but the camera app is downright awful. The only setting to be found is a toggle to switch between the front and rear camera and photo and video mode. That's it, folks. There's nothing else there, well, besides a handful of filters thrown in as an afterthought. The camera app doesn't even allow you to preview the images you capture, you've got to switch to the album app to view your mediocre photos. Poor effort, but let's be honest, most people are (hopefully) never going to use the cameras anyways. Performance and battery These are two areas where the Mi Pad 3 performs surprisingly well.  Here are a couple of benchmarks for the tablet for those of you who insist on such things. On the left is Antutu and on the right GeekBench 4. Now, those numbers may not look very impressive to those who can discern their meaning, but I personally think benchmark numbers are limited in their usefulness. With that in mind, let me tell you how the tablet performs on daily tasks. Apps and games open quickly, and switching between applications doesn't tax the Mi Pad at all. 4GB of RAM is plenty to keep it chugging along. The half dozen games I downloaded on the Mi Pad 3 all played just fine, with only an occasional skipped frame on the most taxing titles. In short, it's actually very pleasant to use. Even when playing a more intense game, like Asphalt 8, the tablet gets just warm enough to be perceptible, and even then it's only the top third of the device where warmth can be felt at all. Not bad, Mediatek. Longevity is quite solid as well. With an ample 6,600mAh battery, I saw between 8-10 hours of screen on time per charge, with a bit less than that when playing a lot of games. That's shorter than the advertised 12 hours of battery life, but it's ample time to keep you entertained during a long flight, or last for a full day of playing Candy Crush while pretending to take notes during business meetings. The only concern I had with battery life is that standby battery drain is higher than I would like to see, with the battery falling 5-8 percent overnight. That's not as good as it could be, but hopefully it's something that can be tightened up in future updates (if there are future updates). Software Speaking of updates, the Mi Pad 3 comes in need of an update right out of the box. It's running Android 7.0, not 7.1, which is a little annoying since 7.1 has been available for several months now. What goes a step beyond annoying to straight up aggravating is that some of the most important features of Nougat are missing in MIUI 8.2. There's no split screen support on the Mi Pad 3, which severely hampers its usefulness as a productivity device. You also can't pin apps, or set up multiple user profiles, and expanded notifications are nowhere to be found. Xiaomi has also done the best it could to mimic Apple by 'iOS'ing the look of app icons, adding a quick ball shortcut tool, and by removing the app drawer. Seriously, manufacturers: leave the app drawer alone! Unlike the build on MIUI found on the Mi Note 2, there doesn't seem to be any way to enable an app drawer, either. I won't harp on this too much, though, as installing a custom launcher is an easy fix to the homescreen set up if it bothers you. Besides the coat of iPaint, the software is fairly bland and unobtrusive. The quantity of pre-installed apps is worthy of praise. There is not a single app on the tablet that I would classify as bloat. There are a couple custom tool apps, like the calculator and notes app, but besides that there's not much else taking up space on the device. This leaves a large portion of the 64GB of on-board storage available for personal use, which is good since there is no expandable memory on the tablet. (The available storage in the image is not indicative of the total storage capacity as additional apps and games were installed on the tablet when I took the screenshot.) There are a few of software touches added by Xioami that I do enjoy. You can wake the tablet with a double tap of the screen, a blue light filter setting is included in  the quick settings shade, and the system animations all look fluid and elegant. The settings menus are also laid out in a manner that I found intuitive and user friendly. Besides that, there's not a lot else to be said. It's a bland version of Nougat that looks like iOS and is missing a couple of useful features. Conclusion It's common knowledge that global tablet sales are down. It seems we, as consumers, have figured out that very few people actually need a tablet. Our phones screens are getting larger, and our laptops are getting thinner and more tablet-like with touchscreens, fold over displays, and lift away bodies. There's just less need for a third device to fit between these two, and most people who need one already have one, and don't have many compelling reasons to upgrade. Most tablets aren't great for productivity, and the Mi Pad 3 is worse than average in that regard. Its predecessor, the Mi Pad 2, rocked Android, but was also available with Windows, making it at least a little business friendly. This new model can't even run split screen apps. Where it does shine is as a media consumption device. With its beautiful screen, competent battery life, and adequate performance, this is a great tablet for killing time during a commute or flight. There is a problem with the Mi Pad 3, though, at least for US based readers: it's way too expensive for what you get. GeekBuying, who supplied our review unit sells them for $250 (thanks guys). For just $50 more you can buy a 128GB iPad Mini 4, or a full-size 32GB iPad. Granted, those are limited time sale prices, but still, you'd have to be kinda nuts to go with the Mi Pad over an iPad. Even as an Android fanatic myself, I readily admit that Apple just does tablet software better. I'm sure I'll take heat for that in the comments, but I doubt any other writer at AP would disagree. If you want a cheap media consumption device, you can pick up an 8 inch Amazon fire tablet for $80-125. The screen won't be as pretty, and the build quality won't be as nice, but for less than half the price you still get a serviceable tablet. At $150-175, the Mi Pad 3 would be easy to recommend to Android purists who want a tablet with nice build quality and a great screen. At $250, with mediocre software and a lengthy list of small irritations, I just don't really know who is going to want to buy this. Perhaps you disagree, so feel free to tell me why in the comments. Also, if there are any questions you still have that weren't answered by the review, drop them below and I'll do my best to answer them. If you want to read more about the tablet, then head on over to GeekBuying and check it out for yourself. Tags Android Tablet Mi Pad 3 tablet xiaomi subscribe ... Well, that ended that discussion. Daniel Marcus Can we get over the stigma around MediaTek already? Their Kernel repository is regularly updated (last push was for Android Wear, about two weeks ago), their chips run cool, their radios have good reception, their reference firmware is highly stable and has great debugging tools for developers, and their flashing software is easy enough to use and their devices are difficult to brick. Their chips aren't the fastest, but they aren't particularly slow. They aren't so far behind in any technical way so as to impact the use of the devices. Frankly, the only thing Qualcomm really has over MediaTek at this point is raw speed, and that comes at the cost of heat and power use. Every time I see Google making changes to Android in the name of battery life, I have to wonder why. MediaTek has had standby power usage on par or better than the current versions of Android with Qualcomm processors for years now. (This tablet has significantly worse standby than the older MediaTek tablet I had that ran near-stock Android 5.1.) We complain that Qualcomm's phones get hot and have to be throttled. We complain that Samsung and often other phones with Qualcomm radios have poor reception. Bluetooth issues have been common, even on Google's own Pixel devices. Qualcomm has dropped support for the Snapdragon 801, and with it many once-flagship devices that won't get Android 7. (MediaTek is still actively adding Android 7 support to older devices, including processors released around the same time as the 801.) I'm not saying MediaTek is perfect, but I think it's time to recognize that Qualcomm isn't some perfect chipset poster child. Just because a device is using a MediaTek chip instead of a Qualcomm doesn't have any real impact on the performance or longevity of the device in daily use. Kevin Davis Nope. Mediatek doesn't have any support in custom ROMs. As soon as Mediatek starts helping developers and release enough info to enable custom ROM developers to support their chipsets, I'll adopt Mediatek as a viable option. Daniel Marcus The second sentence in my post I noted that MediaTek is now regularly updating their source repository. There are several MTK devices that have unlocked bootloaders and fairly decent ROM support (say, the Blu R1 and several Umi devices). The reason for a lack of custom software development is low market penetration, not anything inherent in their chips today. As you have demonstrated, though, people tend to keep old views and all the marketing done around Snapdragon and the importance of benchmarks has led companies to use those chips in major product launches. Similarly, the lack of software updates to MediaTek based devices is mostly because they're cheaper devices that just don't pay to update, not because MediaTek hasn't provided updated firmware for the chipset. My current daily driver is a Blu R1 Plus. It runs pretty much stock Android 6.0 which is, frankly, almost indistinguishable from 7.1. It's snappy, has great reception and battery life, and between VoLTE support and some excellent noise cancellation, the calls are exceptionally clear. Unlike my Nexus 5x, the Bluetooth is very reliable. It's not the fastest device, nor does it have the best camera, and it's a couple of (minor) versions of Android behind. As a phone though, it's exactly what I need. Also, it was $160, so I can't really complain. Random! Let's hope the custom ROM situation keeps improving. Google hires ex-Apple chipset veteran to help design SoCs for Pixel phones Ryne Hager Follow View All Posts 2017/06/13 11:36am PDTJun 13, 2017 46 Plus 1 on G+ 195 Share on Facebook 52 Share on Twitter Total Shares293 Google News Google's hardware plans for the future are getting bigger. Variety is reporting that Google has hired Manu Gulati, a hardware architect, away from Apple. Gulati is reported as having previously played a significant role in the development of Apple's SoCs for the last eight years and was hired sometime in the last few weeks. His new title at Google is Lead SOC Architect, and he's expected to work on custom chipsets for future Pixel phones. If Manu Gulati can apply the same black magic to Google's future products as he did on Apple's custom chips, things could be fantastic. Apple's "A" series chips are amazing pieces of hardware. Though Apple does license ARM's tech, unlike other manufacturers, they don't just toss the licensed reference designs on a wafer. Apple has bent over backward to optimize their silicon architecture for iOS, and the resulting performance on Apple devices definitely demonstrates that. Although some Android chipset vendors, such as Qualcomm, do make custom designs like the Kryo, for whatever reason Apple's custom hardware (combined with their software) has held an edge in performance for years. For most of us, any advantage the A series chips have doesn't make any difference without the Android operating system. But if Google is able to bring the same degree of performance enhancements and customization over into their future hardware, the future of Android SoC performance could be bright. After the dark and regressive ages of the Snapdragon 808/810 and Qualcomm's rushed 64bit development cycle, I would like nothing more than to see Google bring a first party chipset in a future Pixel device. And who knows, they might even sell it to other manufacturers, increasing competition in the currently stagnant mobile chipset space. Gulati joining Google finally lends credence to the old stories of Google's interest in SoC designing. And it appears to be full steam ahead, as supplemental job postings for SoC design have appeared on Google Careers. Whether these efforts result in a new custom chipset by Google, or we just see some new specialized hardware for machine learning, either way, things should be interesting. Godspoken I recall "Google silicon" being referenced last year as a future goal of the Pixel, very exciting. blackice85 Isn't that one of the things holding them back from providing updates for longer periods of time too? Gregory That Project Treble thing or how do you call it in O is also all about cutting on dependencies from third parties like Qualcomm. blackice85 Oh I hadn't heard about that, I bet this is one aspect of it then. Duder12 Project Treble doesnt improve years of update support. It brings updates faster since Qualcomm and OEMs can work on software updates at the same time. Qualcomm can still decide to not ship new drivers for old versions of Android just like they always have. Google doing their own SOC is the only real answer Gregory From my understanding, it eliminates the need for the drivers to be updated in the first place. someone755 You can't expect to not update drivers with new Android versions. Say there's an Android system API that a driver adheres to. As something banal, let's say we have a driver that controls whether the hardware button backlight is on or off, and that the system can control whether it is either on or off. Then a newer Android version appears which supports both the old API but also a newer one, wherein the hardware backlight can be controlled as if it were analog (from 0-255 for example). Then, the third system version comes out that ditches support for the old API and only still supports the newer one. Yes the OEM could hack things up so that values 0-254 would mean the light is off and then 255 would mean it's on, but this further complicates both the user experience and app compatibility as well as future system version compatibility. At this point if you want a stable and future-proof software solution, you absolutely have to update the driver to support the new API. And if the backlight vendor can't provide one, then it's more trouble than it's worth for the OEM to do the hack themselves and they just post a note online saying your device won't get upgraded, leaving you with no choice but to either resort to community hacks or buy a new device. Yes the example is completely idiotic but it serves as an example of why you can't go around updating devices without driver updates. Aside from the functionality aspect there are many security flaws that could affect a driver. And not updating that huge gaping hole in your security while providing monthly 'security patches' that claim to solve security threats is just inane. At that point why even bother with security patches if you can't expect chipset vendors to fix the problems in their closed-source firmware, or hold them accountable for it. Gregory While I completely understand your point, I'd like to extend it to say that there could be such a backlight that can be either on or off, and it's a hardware limitation, so it isn't possible to fully implement the new API on that device. I mean, hardware configurations vary, it's a matter of fact. The point of HAL (hardware abstraction layer) is to abstract away the differences across the underlying hardware, and provide a unified API for the system services to interact with said hardware. If the HAL doesn't provide support for some new feature that was added in a system update but the hardware could technically support it, it still means that the system would behave as though that feature isn't supported by the hardware, and that's it. I'd rather have a device that doesn't support that new feature than a device that is no longer updated. And security... How about people ALWAYS check for buffer boundaries before copying memory? What do they do with all that time and disk space they save? Or, at least, if they're that lazy, run a static analyzer on your code and fix whatever it finds. And run it in valgrind to find memory leaks. It's not that hard to write vulnerability-free code from the start. someone755 But a device will never pass certification, either by Google or an FCC-like entity or another office, with broken features. This is exactly why the 8974 line got dropped -- the hardware didn't support a feature that Google wanted so they didn't let any 8974 device pass CTS. How do you think people running Nougat just fine on their hammerheads (via one custom ROM or another) feel about this conundrum when they've been cut short an entire system update because of Google's insane chip requirements? It's easy to know how to prevent bad code but often times projects start simple and private and unoptimized, and then grow into something much larger that's hard to maintain. A classic example is Android itself (look at all the memory leaks that L introduced). Gregory Well... If a device passed certification by Google (CTS) and carriers, that feature was optional from the beginning, right? Android does already support a plethora of different hardware configurations with different capabilities. If a device didn't have some feature at launch, I don't expect it to have that feature enabled with a software update. CTS is about keeping compatibility with apps (it tests public APIs), it has nothing to do with drivers and hardware. There are literally no hardware requirements that make it impossible to update existing devices more than a year or two. Carrier certification is about device interfacing correctly with carrier equipment, it did so well when it was released and certified, so just don't touch the modem firmware because it's already doing its job good enough, as simple as that. There are exactly zero reasons to modify the HAL for system updates provided HAL and the rest of the system are properly separated, which, from my understanding, they are with Project Treble. It also adds CTS-like standardized test suite for these things. What the hell is 8974? someone755 Msm8974. The Snapdragon 800 platform that phones like the N5, Z3, G2, S5, M8 etc were based on. That got blocked from receiving any sort of updates because Google decided that Vulkan or GL 3.1 was necessary for the upgrade. Not that modern low-end phones are capable of performing the task that the requirement was set for anyways. Basically the thing my entire argument is set around but alright... Owais Lone > Qualcomm can still decide to not ship new drivers for old versions of Android just like they always have. ... and Project Treble will enable device vendors to still ship updates in this exact case. Project Treble cuts out qualcom and SoC manufacturers out of the update cycle. The device vendors will be bottleneck and decision makers now. someone755 This is incorrect. Please see my reply to Gregory above. Owais Lone Your example exactly illustrates the problem now. Project Treble is supposed to abstract these internal hardware level ABIs/APIs so vendors don't have to re-implement the whole layer again. Only time when SOC vendors will have to update their code is when Project Treble itself comes out with a breaking change and a major version upgrade. Of course, vendors might have to or want to make changes here and there but the abstraction should save them from re-doing all of it on every update and if the vendor does not want to improve/optimize with every update, they shouldn't have to make any changes at all unless Treble itself comes out with an incompatible update. someone755 And say that Android P is the one where the button backlight brightness from my example becomes an analog value and the digital on/off API is dropped. Then the phones that incorporate this function will either have to have the driver updated or will not get updated to the next Android version. This is a problem and always will be, as long as chip vendors are not held responsible and held to a higher standard, and as long as the entities that certify devices for daily use (CTS, FCC etc) have some standards themselves (in the sense of not letting devices with broken/missing core features pass). Owais Lone If such a change happens at the HW level, it'll be abstracted at the treble API level so phones that leverage treble API will not need any change at all. Vendors would need to update their code if the change happened in Treble's apI itself which is extremely unlikely as it'll defeat the purpose of having Treble in the first place. That said, there will be major updates to Treble which might break backward compatibility but it's Google's job to keep those changes at a minimal or the whole idea will be worthless. someone755 This is exactly what I'm saying -- if Treble changes (which it most probably will across Android versions, as the system has changed until now), the chip vendors will *have* to provide updates. And there is no way around this limitation, Treble or not, if Google makes some absurd changes then phones won't get updated. Owais Lone Yes, that is true but why would that happen in the first place? That would completely defeat the purpose. Treble will most likely always be backward compatible. It'll probably only add new features and new APIs but not break existing ones. That's how I would handle the project. One core would be almost always in use for background tasks, and as such would burn through battery. Android is not that dissimilar, it has far more background activity than iOS, and therefore needs less powerful, more numerous cores that use less power. The trick is making all those cores useful when you need to run a single powerful task. This is something that Android has got much better at, but it doesnt really show up well in benchmarks. Thinker Wrong. Anandtech: "The new Kryo 280, despite the similar name, shares no design DNA with the original Kryo. Its an octa-core, big.LITTLE configuration with four “performance” cores and four lower-power “efficiency” cores. What makes Kryo 280 unique, however, is that it’s the first design to use ARM’s new "Built on ARM Cortex Technology" (BoC) license, which allows vendors to customize ARM cores. This new semi-custom option gives vendors the ability to differentiate their products from those using ARM’s stock cores while avoiding the more costly route of creating a fully-custom design from scratch." Again, like I said above, S835 CPU core was a step BACKWARDS. It is basically a generic CPU core with memory controller from Qualcomm. S820 used custom cores but with S835, Qualcomm used generic. Again, you never answered my other question. How many instruction set per cycle can A10 do vs S835? STFU dude. You are ignorant. Just_No_Stop You realise that a SoC isnt just the cores right? Again, you lack understanding, all you can do is regurgitate rubbish you have read on a website. Exynos is almost entirely ARM reference, the 835 is not, generic cores maybe, but otherwise completely custom. Sadly all that customisation results in lower performance, not more. Why does it matter how many instructions per cycle it can do? What matters is the total performance. Google) would purchase MediaTek and position them to actually compete with Snapdragon, so that we could all benefit from longer/quicker upgrades, not to mention performance. someone755 MediaTek's strategy is much like AMD's was just a few years ago in the desktop space. The money for them is up to where OEMs (who make low-end and midrange phones) are willing to pay for the chips -- any higher and they don't have the knowledge/technology/budget to produce something more powerful. Any lower and, well, this is as low as it can go, and the other competitors (Qualcomm, Intel) have worse-performing chips available for the price that MediaTek offers theirs at. Why that is, I have no clue, but I suspect it could have something to do with Qcom having a monopoly on ARM-based chips, and Intel thinking that their overpriced-desktop-chips-with-no-competitor strategy is going to work here, in a highly competitive environment. The point here being that MediaTek works off tight margins and sells in large quantities. Restructuring this process so that it fits our idea of a Qualcomm competitor would be expensive, and definitely riskier than what the payoff is worth to the investor. reggjoo Maybe he can help bring that single core performance up to apple levels. The Best Blue-Chip Stocks AdChoices Big investors, unfazed by techs' roller coaster, buy 'FANG' stocks Reuters By David Randall 2 days ago SHARE SHARE TWEET SHARE EMAIL The value of a dollar in each state 50 most valuable brands in the world © REUTERS/Regis Duvignau/File Photo FILE PHOTO: The Apple logo is seen on a computer screen in an illustration photo taken in Bordeaux, France Large investors, whose high exposure to large-cap technology stocks boosted their returns during the first quarter of the year, are doubling down on their investments even as stocks like Apple Inc and Facebook Inc stumble. Quotes in the article Apple Inc AAPL ▼ 144.29 -0.87 -0.60% Amazon.com Inc AMZN ▼ 964.17 -12.30 -1.26% Facebook Inc FB ▼ 149.80 -0.45 -0.30% T. Rowe Price Group Inc TROW ▲ 73.25 +0.01 +0.01% AdChoices Fund managers such as T Rowe Price and Federated Investors, who were already overweight the sector, said they were buying beaten-down so-called 'FANG' stocks – Facebook, Amazon.com Inc, Netflix Inc and Google-parent Alphabet Inc - during a two-day selloff that marked the largest tech sector decline in nearly a year. Google, Apple and other large tech stocks rose modestly in morning trading Tuesday. Jeff Rottinghaus, portfolio manager of the T Rowe Price Large-Cap Core Equity fund, said he has been adding money to existing tech holdings such as Facebook and Amazon because they are positioned to continue to grow over the next few years regardless of the direction of the overall economy. With other secular growth stories hard to find, "It's getting to the point where you have to say, 'What else do you want me to own?'" he said, adding that these companies continue to be up significantly year-to-date despite recent declines. Analysts expect the S&P 500 technology index to grow its earnings by 12.4 percent this year, better than the S&P 500's 11.6-percent expected growth, according to Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S. About 40 percent of the stocks in the S&P 500 information technology index rose on Monday, including Qualcomm Inc and International Business Machines Corp, which have lagged in 2017. "This tech selloff is a great buying opportunity," said Navellier & Associates Chairman Louis Navellier, who bought shares of Micron Technology Inc, Applied Materials Inc, Arista Networks Inc and STMicroelectronics NV. In the 8-year-old bull market, investors have consistently been 'buying the dips,' taking advantage of brief pullbacks in prices, so large-cap stocks have not seen a 10-percent correction in well over a year. Although stocks are expensive by historical measures, bullish investors say they are justified by growth in earnings and the U.S. economy, while historically low bond yields are also making stocks more appealing. © REUTERS/Leonhard Foeger/File Photo FILE PHOTO: A zoomed illustration image of a man looking at a computer monitor showing the logo of Amazon is seen in Vienna COMEBACK OF THE 'TRUMP TRADE?' The stumble in tech comes a time when both mutual funds and hedge funds have taken outsized bets on the sector, helping push Facebook, Amazon, Apple and Microsoft to add a total $600 billion in market cap year-to-date. Tech stocks in the S&P 500 rallied 21 percent for the year through June 2nd, with the largest companies accounting for 46 percent of the S&P 500's 9-percent gain, according to Goldman Sachs. That rally sent some tech-heavy tech funds soaring. In May, Light Street Capital Management's $1.2-billion Halogen fund was up 11 percent and is up 42.6 percent this year through the end of May. The head of the fund, Glen Kacher, started his career at Tiger Management, Julian Robertson's famous fund. Yet concerns that fund managers had piled into the same stocks and stretched their valuations helped prompt a selloff that began Friday and continued through Monday, sapping 5 percent or more from companies such as Apple. Momentum-based technology stocks have "built a valuation air pocket underneath [them] creating cause for pause," Goldman Sachs wrote in a note Friday. Steve Chiavarone, a portfolio manager at Federated Investors in New York, said he saw the tech selloff as a sign that investors were feeling more confident that the Trump administration could pass infrastructure or tax legislation later this year. Last week's testimony by former FBI chief James Comey did not contain the sort of bombshell that investors had feared, Chiavarone said, prompting fund managers to rotate out of tech into sectors that have lagged. "It allowed folks to believe once again that Congress isn't going to be bogged down in a massive impeachment effort and could get some policy work done," he said, which would benefit energy and financial stocks that initially rallied following Trump's unexpected victory but lost their gains following Inauguration Day. (Additional reporting by Noel Randewich and Trevor Hunnicutt; Editing by Jennifer Ablan, Megan Davies and Nick Zieminski) Go to MSN Home Go to MSN Money Join the conversation Report Abuse Report inappropriate content Sorry! Veuer 1 Cancel SETTINGS OFF HD HQ SD LO Market's cross-currents make sense of the selloff CNBC See more videos SHARE SHARE TWEET SHARE EMAIL What to watch next Popular German grocery store chain opens to much fanfare in US Business Insider1:30 How the Fed rate hike will affect your finances CNBC0:58 Complaints against US airlines up 70% Veuer0:59 US blames North Korea for spree of global hacking Reuters1:14 Snap eyes augmented future for spectacles Wochit Tech0:44 The 'most interesting man in the world' is back – and he's no longer drinking beer Business Insider1:05 Your airline coach seat is shrinking. Here's why The Wall Street Journal.1:57 Board member's comment about women highlights Uber's troubles – again Newsy0:57 Arab rift with Qatar is causing operational problems, IEA warns CNBC0:45 Why we spend so much time and money at Target Veuer0:56 United employee shoves elderly man CNN Money2:08 Don't be a fool for gold The Wall Street Journal.2:05 When Sears sold cars CNN Money0:57 Watch rock turn into steel at 3,000 degrees CNN Money1:55 The fabulous life and career of 33-year-old Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg Business Insider2:27 Bill Gross says all financial markets are 'increasingly at risk' CNBC0:47 UP NEXT Stocks ended higher Tuesday as large-cap technology stocks stabilized after their biggest two-day decline since December. Quotes in the article Apple Inc AAPL ▼ 144.29 -0.87 -0.60% CME Group Inc CME ▼ 126.78 -0.54 -0.42% AdChoices The Dow gained 92 points to close at a record-high 21,328. The S&P 500 gained 0.45 percent, with information technology leading advancers. Shares of Apple, Google-Parent Alphabet and Tesla all rose, pushing the Nasdaq composite 0.73 percent higher.  Katie Stockton, chief technical strategist at BTIG, said the Nasdaq 100 futures had taken a respite Tuesday before the bell "from the pullback that has characterized the technology sector in the last two days." "There is room to short-term oversold territory, so we would assume the pullback still has a hold, although it is likely to mature in the next few days," Stockton said. Technology stocks have easily outperformed this year, with the S&P information technology sector advancing 17.6 percent. By comparison, health care — the second-best performer in the S&P — had risen 12.1 for 2017 entering Tuesday's session. The Nasdaq completed a 2.31 percent two-day pullback Monday as valuation concerns around the sector escalated. A survey of fund managers released Tuesday by Bank of America Merrill Lynch showed the Nasdaq at the top of the most-crowded trade list. The survey also showed that 84 percent of fund managers believe the U.S. is the most overvalued equity market. Load Error Still, it's "important to note that the last two days have shown little to no real signs of weakness with pullback attempts in S&P, DJIA holding and rallying back to unchanged," said Mark Newton, managing partner at Newton Advisors, in a note. "The Tech selloff looks nearly complete in the short run with XLK ... down to weekly support near trendlines from last November," he said. Investors also kept an eye on the Federal Reserve as the central bank kicked off a two-day monetary policy meeting on Tuesday. Investors largely expect the central bank to raise interest rates by a quarter point. Market expectations for a June rate hike were 99.6 percent, according to the CME Group's FedWatch tool. Investors will also look for clues about how the Fed plans to unwind its massive $4.5 trillion balance sheet. In economic news, the National Federation of Independent Business' (NFIB) small business optimism index came in unchanged at 104.5 for May. "The bottom line continues to be that small businesses remain hopeful for positive policy changes out of the [Trump] Administration," said Peter Boockvar, chief market analyst at The Lindsey Group. "Companies are still hiring but not really increasing investments in their business. On the former, a growing issue is the dearth of supply for qualified workers which we keep talking about," Boockvar said. Meanwhile, U.S. producer prices remained unchanged last month as energy costs recorded their biggest decline in more than a year, suggesting inflation pressures were easing after rising at the start of the year. Reuters contributed to this report. Go to MSN Home Go to MSN Money Join the conversation Report Abuse Report inappropriate content Sorry! There was a problem. Please try again. Macs already on the developer beta can update through the Mac App Store. Registered developers can also access the update through the Apple Developer Connection. Apple hasn’t announced any new features in the developer seeds of macOS Sierra 10.12.6, and it is most likely a maintenance release. Any remaining macOS Sierra releases are most likely to be maintenance and/or security-focused as the company ramps up to macOS High Sierra this fall. View All Reviews → Not Everyone Will Be Able to Afford the New iMac Pro, and That's Okay Drive Genius 5: Guardian of Your Disks No, the iMac Pro Apple Tax Isn't a Real Thing UK Election Throws Encryption Erosion into Doubt Believe It or Not, the Camera Phone Turned 20 Today View All Editorials → Tim Cook: Apple is Making Self-driving Car Software Jeff Gamet @jgamet · +Jeff Gamet 1 minute read Jun 13th, 2017 10:24 AM EDT | News Apple CEO Tim Cook is being uncharacteristically candid because he just confirmed his company is working on a self-driving car project. He says Apple is working on the software for self-driving cars, and that artificial intelligence is a big part of the project. In an interview with Bloomberg Cook said, We’re focusing on autonomous systems. It’s a core technology that we view as very important. We sort of see it as the mother of all AI projects. Reports of the Apple Car project, dubbed Titan, have been circulating for the past couple years. Until now, however, there’s hasn’t been any sort of official confirmation from Cupertino. Apple’s self-driving car project is all about the software, at least for now Apple seems more interested in the software to make cars self-driving as opposed to making its own autonomous vehicle. That seems to be a change from the company’s earlier effort where reports said Apple wanted to make its own self-driving electric car. Focusing on the software side of self-driving cars may be Bob Mansfield’s doing. Cook assigned him to Project Titan last summer and by fall people were being laid off amidst reports that Mansfield was shifting the focus away from an actual car. With the actual car off the table the question now is about the software: How does Apple plan to use the platform it’s making? Mr. Cook isn’t saying, but it’s likely some sort of partnership is coming. Without a car manufacturer on board, Apple’s self-driving software won’t be of much use. That said, there’s still a chance Apple could end up making its own car. “We’ll see where it takes us. We’re not really saying from a product point of view what we will do,” he said. Translation: Tim Cook confirmed Apple is developing software for self-driving cars, but he won’t confirm how it’s going to be used. Share this: Facebook Twitter Google LinkedIn Reddit More Print Tumblr Tags: car, Project Titan, self-driving, Tim Cook You might also like… Get Free Bitcoins from 22 Faucets That Pay How to Downgrade from iOS 11 Beta No, the iMac Pro Apple Tax Isn't a Real Thing Post WWDC: Has Apple Fixed Everything, or do Weaknesses Remain? Top 6 Free Mac Security Tools 2 Comments Add a comment CudaBoy June 13, 2017 Looks like I nailed this one, too. A “system” is what I proposed Apple would do waaaay back when the clones here thought Apple was going to make a car. So here’s the deal. No major car company here in the US will use Apple’s “system” for retail sales but possibly for fleets of Ubers or something like that. Maybe in China some company would give up control of the “brains” of the car but NOT any US mfg. Anybody doubt this theory? After Apple successfully sells the system to some fleets or foreign mfgs if at that point they “care” about owning the whole widget they would possibly look into mfg their own cars here or somewhere else for import. IMO, Apple’s huge treasure trove of cash which is doing the planet NO GOOD for years now, could be spent on something more beneficial than a car. View All Reviews → Not Everyone Will Be Able to Afford the New iMac Pro, and That's Okay Drive Genius 5: Guardian of Your Disks No, the iMac Pro Apple Tax Isn't a Real Thing UK Election Throws Encryption Erosion into Doubt Believe It or Not, the Camera Phone Turned 20 Today View All Editorials → 10.5-inch and 12.9-inch iPad Pro Available in Apple Stores Jeff Gamet @jgamet · +Jeff Gamet 1 minute read Jun 13th, 2017 11:55 AM EDT | Product News Apple’s brand new 10.5-inch iPad Pro and just updated 12.9-inch model are now available in the company’s retail stores. Both models were introduced last week at Apple’s annual Worldwide Developer Conference in San Jose, California. 10.5-inch and 12.9-inch iPad Pro now available in Apple’s stores The new iPad Pro models sport Apple’s A10X processor, embedded M10 processor, ProMotion Retina displays with True Tone wide and wide color gamut, 802.11a/b/g/n/ac WiFi, Bluetooth 4.2, Touch ID support, four speakers, front and rear-facing cameras, Smart Connector and Lightning connector. Both models are available in Space Gray, Gold, and Silver in 64 GB, 256 GB, and 512 GB capacities. The 10.5-inch version is also available in Rose Gold. The Mac Observer’s checks showed the 10.5-inch model in stock in every store we checked. The 12.9-inch model, however, was hit and miss with some locations showing it wouldn’t be in store for at least another week. Pricing for the 10.5-inch model starts at US$649 for the 64 GB model, and $799 for the 12.9-inch 64 GB model. Both support Apple’s $99 Apple Pencil. Apps iPhone Apps iPad Apps Mac Apps Apple TV Apps Apple Watch Apps The Best Apps Tutorials Jailbreak Jailbreak Tweaks Jailbreak Guide Unlock Guide Deals Latest Deals Devices iPhone iPad Mac Apple Watch Apple TV More Download Wallpapers iPhone Photography Expert Tips Podcasts Apple seeds third betas of iOS 10.3.3, macOS 10.12.6, watchOS 3.2.3 & tvOS 10.2.2 Christian Zibreg on June 13, 2017 8 Apple on Tuesday seeded new betas to members of the Apple Developer Program. iOS 10.3.3 beta 3 (build 14G5047a), macOS Sierra 10.12.6 beta 3 (build 16G16b), watchOS 3.2.3 beta 3 (build 14V5744a) and tvOS 10.2.2 beta 3 (build 14W5745a) are all now available to deploy on registered devices that have an appropriate configuration. Just use the standard Software Update mechanism to install the latest beta updates. Full installers can be downloaded through Apple’s Dev Center. These are maintenance updates with bug fixes and stability improvements. Should we discover any new user-facing features, we’ll make sure to update this article. Xiaomi Mi Pad 3 review: For those who dream of owning an iPad mini that runs Android Jeff Beck Follow View All Posts 2017/06/12 12:00pm PDTJun 12, 2017 3 Plus 1 on G+ 51 Share on Facebook 33 Share on Twitter Total Shares87 Mi Pad 3 News Reviews Tablet Reviews Xiaomi / MIUI Article Contents 1 Specs 2 The Good 3 The Not So Good 4 Design 5 Display 6 Cameras 7 Performance and battery 8 Software 9 Conclusion Have you ever walked through a mall and passed by the Apple store and stared longingly at the iPad Mini and thought to yourself, "Man, I sure wish I could buy one of those that ran Android"? Well, I have some (kinda) good news for you. Today I'm reviewing the Xiaomi Mi Pad 3, a 7.9in Chinese tablet that has no shame in borrowing a healthy dose of design cues from a certain fruit logo-bearing competitor. For better or worse, the Mi Pad 3 looks an awful lot like an iPad Mini in Android clothing. Is it as good, or better than the tablet it is imitating? Let's find out. Specs SoC Mediatek MT8176 RAM 4GB Storage 64GB Display 7.9-inch 1536 x 2048 IPS LCD Battery 6,600 mAh Camera 13MP, 5MP Software Android 7.0, MIUI8 Measurements 200.4 x 132.6 x 7 mm, 328g The Good Design and build If you like the design and build quality of the iPad mini, you will like the way this looks and feels. Performance Yes, it's a Mediatek processor, but during my month of testing it's been quite a solid performer. Display The display is rumored to be the same one used in the iPad mini; it's crisp, vibrant, and responsive. Battery Longevity is good, with 8-10 hours of screen on time. The Not So Good Speakers They sound ok, but their placement is lousy. Capacitive buttons Come on, even Samsung gave those up. Software Running Android 7.0, but key features are missing. No fingerprint reader This is something that's become a standard feature in the last year, it sucks to go back to PIN unlocking. Camera Come on, no one expects a tablet camera to be any good, and Xiaomi doesn't disappoint - this one is lousy. Design It's impossible to look at the Mi Pad 3 and not be reminded of an iPad mini. The looks are strikingly similar, intentionally so. The size, weight, thickness, bezels, and camera placement are all almost identical. The back is a flat slab of aluminum with rounded sides, similar to - you guessed it - the iPad mini. Really, the only things that set it apart from the iPad are the placement of the speakers and buttons, and the lack of a home button on the front. Yeah, it's pretty much a blatant copy, but at least the source material is well designed. Hate on Apple all you want, the iPad mini is a nice looking device that's easy to hold, and so is the Mi Pad 3 by extension. Let's take a little tour of the tablet. At the top left corner of the device is a headphone jack, and centered at the bottom of the tablet is a USB-C port. The left side is bare and the right side features a power bottom and volume rocker about an inch below the top. The buttons are the only parts that feel a bit cheap on this tablet. While they are made of aluminum and have nice feedback, they are a bit too loose in their sockets, which makes them wiggle when touched and rattle when shaken. A small thing, but hard to ignore once you notice it. The front of the device is dominated by the display, surrounded by black bezels of moderate size top and bottom. The navigation buttons are back-lit capacitive keys at the bottom of the display arranged in the Samsung fashion, which feels backwards to many users, including myself. That's two things I really don't care for in one aspect of the tablet. Now, the buttons can be remapped in the settings to change the back button to the left and menu to the right. However, the icons can't be changed as they are back-lit cutouts, so instead of fixing the layout, it makes it even worse as the icons no longer match their actions. On the plus side, the duration that the buttons stay lit can be adjusted, or the back-light can be disabled completely system wide, or while using specific apps. You might have noticed that the home button is not a fingerprint scanner as it is on the iPad mini. There isn't one anywhere else on the device either, nor is there NFC, or a microSD card slot. Now, 64GB of internal space helps offset the need for expandable storage, and you're not likely to use a tablet to pay for your groceries with Android Pay, but the missing fingerprint scanner is frustrating. That's become a pretty standard feature on devices in 2017, and I miss it here. Going back to using a pin number to unlock my device feels archaic. Funny how quickly times change. Flipping the device over, there's not a lot going on. A 13MP camera occupies the upper left corner, and twin speakers sit at the bottom of the rear panel spaced an inch and a half apart. The speakers are stereo, which is laughable as an inch and a half of separation is barely sufficient for your ears to distinguish the difference between the channels. They are also completely useless as stereo speakers when holding the tablet in landscape mode, the way I assume 99 percent of people orient their tablet when watching a movie. They still play audio in stereo when the tablet is oriented in landscape, meaning you have a top and bottom channel instead of a right and left channel. That's just bizarre. In terms of volume, the speakers are about as loud as you'd expect with a tablet this size. In a quiet room they are perfectly fine for watching a show or playing a game. They don't have any low end, but they are clear and distortion free. Audio from the headphone jack is great, with enough power to drive a set of 50mm headphones well above a comfortable listening level. Taken as a whole, the tablet is very well constructed and feels light yet solid in hand. There are no gaps, the glass panel on the front is completely uniform, and weight is evenly distributed across the device. If you want to get a good approximation for how it feels to hold one, get your hands on an iPad mini. A tech novice might not even be able to tell them apart with a blindfold on. Display The highlight of the Mi Pad 3 is definitely the IPS LCD display. Its resolution of 2048×1536 is identical to that of the screen found in the iPad mini. It's rumored that the display is, in fact, sourced from the same supplier as the one that adorns Apple's smallest tablet. That wouldn't surprise me at all, as it is quite brilliant. Colors are deep and rich, black levels are respectable, and the white balance is well calibrated. It has all the nits you need for outdoor viewing, and even more importantly, in my opinion, it can drop to delightfully low brightness levels for late night use. The LCD panel can dim even further than the AMOLED screen on my Nexus 6P, something I find impressive. A number of tweaks can be made to the screen through the settings panel. The tint can be adjusted and a black and white mode can also be enabled to supposedly increase battery life. I don't believe color has the same impact on power consumption on an LCD panel as it does on an AMOLED display, but the setting is there nonetheless and will make Gothic and noir fans happy. There's also a reading mode that amps up the red levels for nighttime viewing, a feature I always love to see implemented on the system level. Cameras Frankly, I sometimes wonder why we even bother with this section in tablet reviews. There seems to be an unwritten law that tablet cameras must be lousy, and man, Xiaomi is a law-abiding company in that regard. I've take a few shots for you to look at, because, hey, I already spent some time typing a header for this section, so why not. Previous Next At first blush the pictures look acceptable, but once you take a closer look it's apparent that the images are bland, soft, and lacking vibrancy. All these were taken with the 13MP rear camera, the photos from the front facing camera were even worse. The selfies I took made me look absolutely awful, so I vainly excluded them from the review. The image quality is mediocre, even for a tablet, but the camera app is downright awful. The only setting to be found is a toggle to switch between the front and rear camera and photo and video mode. That's it, folks. There's nothing else there, well, besides a handful of filters thrown in as an afterthought. The camera app doesn't even allow you to preview the images you capture, you've got to switch to the album app to view your mediocre photos. Poor effort, but let's be honest, most people are (hopefully) never going to use the cameras anyways. Performance and battery These are two areas where the Mi Pad 3 performs surprisingly well.  Here are a couple of benchmarks for the tablet for those of you who insist on such things. On the left is Antutu and on the right GeekBench 4. Now, those numbers may not look very impressive to those who can discern their meaning, but I personally think benchmark numbers are limited in their usefulness. With that in mind, let me tell you how the tablet performs on daily tasks. Apps and games open quickly, and switching between applications doesn't tax the Mi Pad at all. 4GB of RAM is plenty to keep it chugging along. The half dozen games I downloaded on the Mi Pad 3 all played just fine, with only an occasional skipped frame on the most taxing titles. In short, it's actually very pleasant to use. Even when playing a more intense game, like Asphalt 8, the tablet gets just warm enough to be perceptible, and even then it's only the top third of the device where warmth can be felt at all. Not bad, Mediatek. Longevity is quite solid as well. With an ample 6,600mAh battery, I saw between 8-10 hours of screen on time per charge, with a bit less than that when playing a lot of games. That's shorter than the advertised 12 hours of battery life, but it's ample time to keep you entertained during a long flight, or last for a full day of playing Candy Crush while pretending to take notes during business meetings. The only concern I had with battery life is that standby battery drain is higher than I would like to see, with the battery falling 5-8 percent overnight. That's not as good as it could be, but hopefully it's something that can be tightened up in future updates (if there are future updates). Software Speaking of updates, the Mi Pad 3 comes in need of an update right out of the box. It's running Android 7.0, not 7.1, which is a little annoying since 7.1 has been available for several months now. What goes a step beyond annoying to straight up aggravating is that some of the most important features of Nougat are missing in MIUI 8.2. There's no split screen support on the Mi Pad 3, which severely hampers its usefulness as a productivity device. You also can't pin apps, or set up multiple user profiles, and expanded notifications are nowhere to be found. Xiaomi has also done the best it could to mimic Apple by 'iOS'ing the look of app icons, adding a quick ball shortcut tool, and by removing the app drawer. Seriously, manufacturers: leave the app drawer alone! Unlike the build on MIUI found on the Mi Note 2, there doesn't seem to be any way to enable an app drawer, either. I won't harp on this too much, though, as installing a custom launcher is an easy fix to the homescreen set up if it bothers you. Besides the coat of iPaint, the software is fairly bland and unobtrusive. The quantity of pre-installed apps is worthy of praise. There is not a single app on the tablet that I would classify as bloat. There are a couple custom tool apps, like the calculator and notes app, but besides that there's not much else taking up space on the device. This leaves a large portion of the 64GB of on-board storage available for personal use, which is good since there is no expandable memory on the tablet. (The available storage in the image is not indicative of the total storage capacity as additional apps and games were installed on the tablet when I took the screenshot.) There are a few of software touches added by Xioami that I do enjoy. You can wake the tablet with a double tap of the screen, a blue light filter setting is included in  the quick settings shade, and the system animations all look fluid and elegant. The settings menus are also laid out in a manner that I found intuitive and user friendly. Besides that, there's not a lot else to be said. It's a bland version of Nougat that looks like iOS and is missing a couple of useful features. Conclusion It's common knowledge that global tablet sales are down. It seems we, as consumers, have figured out that very few people actually need a tablet. Our phones screens are getting larger, and our laptops are getting thinner and more tablet-like with touchscreens, fold over displays, and lift away bodies. There's just less need for a third device to fit between these two, and most people who need one already have one, and don't have many compelling reasons to upgrade. Most tablets aren't great for productivity, and the Mi Pad 3 is worse than average in that regard. Its predecessor, the Mi Pad 2, rocked Android, but was also available with Windows, making it at least a little business friendly. This new model can't even run split screen apps. Where it does shine is as a media consumption device. With its beautiful screen, competent battery life, and adequate performance, this is a great tablet for killing time during a commute or flight. There is a problem with the Mi Pad 3, though, at least for US based readers: it's way too expensive for what you get. GeekBuying, who supplied our review unit sells them for $250 (thanks guys). For just $50 more you can buy a 128GB iPad Mini 4, or a full-size 32GB iPad. Granted, those are limited time sale prices, but still, you'd have to be kinda nuts to go with the Mi Pad over an iPad. Even as an Android fanatic myself, I readily admit that Apple just does tablet software better. I'm sure I'll take heat for that in the comments, but I doubt any other writer at AP would disagree. If you want a cheap media consumption device, you can pick up an 8 inch Amazon fire tablet for $80-125. The screen won't be as pretty, and the build quality won't be as nice, but for less than half the price you still get a serviceable tablet. At $150-175, the Mi Pad 3 would be easy to recommend to Android purists who want a tablet with nice build quality and a great screen. At $250, with mediocre software and a lengthy list of small irritations, I just don't really know who is going to want to buy this. Perhaps you disagree, so feel free to tell me why in the comments. Also, if there are any questions you still have that weren't answered by the review, drop them below and I'll do my best to answer them. If you want to read more about the tablet, then head on over to GeekBuying and check it out for yourself. Tags Android Tablet Mi Pad 3 tablet xiaomi subscribe ... Nathan J There really aren't any great new Android tablets. But, for those who like Android but not necessarily for Android apps, but more the tinkering aspect, I would urge you to go Raspberry Pi. There's a 7" touch screen you can get for it, and a case that holds the screen, the Pi, and a battery (power pack). So while not as portable as a tablet (it's like a tablet with a big hump on the back), it's totally tinker friendly, hardware and software. If you think, "I like tinkering on Android, but I'll void the warranty and there are obstacles," get a Pi and mess around with it. And everything runs off a microSD card, so get several and rotate projects. I'm a big fan of one called RetroPie. ;) Тарас Мукин I don't really get the point of small tablets anymore.
